reviewText: This is a great season and this is a really good series! It took HBO long enough to come out with the DVDs.

In terms of fictional series, HBO is the only real reason to own a television set.
The Wire is the best of the HBO Original Series. And the most underappreciated. The only criticism one may have of The Wire is that it is too complicated. But in actuality, I think this is The Wire's best selling point. It's a rarity in television to find a series that compels the viewer to rise to the level of the writing instead of the typical lowering of the writing's quality to dumb it down to attract the most mass appeal to sell ad slots. That's the beauty of HBO - you've bought the service, so you get what you pay for or cancel your subscription. HBO is not targeting the unwashed masses to sell ads, it puts out quality television to attract subscribers. It's a beautiful system that I believe (you heard it here first) will someday become the norm in cable television (channel-by-channel subscription with no advertising).
HBO's format raises the quality and The Wire epitomizes the beauty of this system the most of all HBO Original Series. The plot is so complicated, so multi-layered that I keep watching over and over just to make sure I get it all. I feel that I am failing as a human being if I don't do The Wire justice and get the whole plot line straight. You can't criticize the Wire for being too complicated; it's quite refreshing to have a television show that challenges me as the viewer instead of spoon feeds me.
In 1961, FCC Chairman Newton R. Minow said that television was a "Vaste Wasteland." He was right. HBO wasn't founded until 1971 and The Wire didn't premier until 2002.

I think The Wire, both the first and second seasons, represents the best television ever has offered. The plot is so intricate and plays out as a puzzle of fascinating pieces. Acting, brilliant writing, a boatload of memorable characters and moments -- The Wire has it all. It can be a bit confusing at first and it is best to watch the first two episodes in one sitting. Try it, you'll love it.

First and foremost, David Simon is a genius. Homicide: A year on the Killing Streets, The Corner, both amazing stories and shows. The acting is brillinat, with each side of the "drug war" having their own problems which shape perspectives.
Aside from the above rant, the show ranks as one of the best shows on TV currently, and will go down in history as a fantastic character study.

I wanted to somehow incorporate the word renaissance into this review, and find a clever way to call "television in the last 4 years or so" a renaissance. For lack of creativity I'll take a personal stance for this.
I was never a regular television viewer. I always preferred the VHS and later the DVD over watching a television program. Seemed like such devotion to be there every week. But what was sparked by an interesting premise, 24 hours in the life of the counter terrorist agent, and each episode in real time, lured me in. I fell for 24, than I fell for the Shield when it premiered later a few months after 24 did. I am still thankful I saw "The Shield" advertisement on the corner of 39th and 9th Avenue.
I always saw posters for The Wire on the Path Train. Had no idea what it was all about. I was chalking it up to another spy type show that ABC would produce perhaps. I heard all the critical acclaim, still didn't bite. Than I saw that HBO On Demand was showing episodes 1 through 5. So I tuned in. Watched all 5 episodes in one day. Went back and put them on a blank tape. I'm glad I didn't have to long for HBO to put a new batch of episodes On Demand. They showed 6-10 next. And that's when it got so damn hard. Episode 10 ends in such a cliffhanger and (for those who have the On Demand channels) the next set of episodes wasn't set to be available for 4 weeks or so.
And thus my life for the beginning of this year was all about when the next batch of episodes would cycle through On Demand. I thought about savoring them too, when the middle of season 2 was shown I thought of watching one a week..it could never happen though.
I could have reviewed the show and talk about the characters and the plot that just keeps going, two seasons now, with season three on the way. But it's the experience that should be the selling point. For those who have seen the show know what I mean. It almost hurts to have to wait a whole week to see "what happens next". For those who have never seen the show feel happy that you can now see all of Season 1, at once.
24, The Shield, The Sopranos, Deadwood, and of course The Wire. It's a pretty fair arguement, or rather I can arguement my point well. Does television get any better than this?

I was living in Baltimore when this was being filmed and shown on HBO. I have driven through the streets of Baltimore, seen the docks and the Harbor up close and from a distance on the beltway, I have seen neighborhoods like the ones shown. This is a gritty no holds barred show with awesome characters and acting. It is written by a former Baltimore reporter, the characters based on actual drug kingpins. A former kingpin is an actor on the show who, ironically, plays a minister. Many Baltimore actors are used in the show. It is the best crime drama ever written and I highly recommend it to anyone. It starts a bit slow, but hooks you right into it. I live on the West Coast now. I do miss Baltimore, the accents, "Lake Trout", which isn't trout and isn't from a lake either, crabs, the O's, the Ravens etc. I have watched this series a few times over. I have never tired of it.

One of the best shows not just on HBO, but one of the best of all time.  I have to especially give praise to Michael Kenneth Williams, for his wonderful performance as the best character on the show, Omar Little.

The picture is 16:9 which I consider excellent for my television. The audio is 5.1 surround sound which I consider excellent for my sound system. I do realize that this series is one of the best crime dramas ever. I like to watch this type of program. I like violence on my television It has shooting, punching, kicking and everything of all the action. This is just season one of many and I suppose I'll be watching all the rest.

THE WIRE SEASON 1 ..... SEESAW inner city crime drama.  Some episodes are very good while others are only average.  Additionally there is an overuse of profanity and a constant pushing of gay agenda. ---  I've met and interacted with plenty of gang bangers / retired gang bangers as well as cops/retired cops and the depicted behaviour in this series is exagerated and at times completely phony. -- As there is no central character in the series it is more difficult to focus on certain characters and the characters don't stand out as much. --- Season 1 is OK but If u want to watch a worlds better series watch "The Shield"  Seasons 1-7.  Season 1 starts off a little slower and then BAM it just kicks hard into high gear all the way through season 7. Hope this helps u out.

It's easy to see why this has been regarded as one of the best television series ever - including the very best ever, by some. However one needs to be patient and pay close attention, or much can be missed or not understood. In it's day one of the leading criticisms of the show was the over complicated plots and excessive number of main or, at least regular characters that a viewer had to follow. Those reasons likely contributing to it's only moderate run of five seasons.and generally less than stellar ratings. And even though it never won any major awards, most of the cast, as an ensemble was certainly considerably above average. The stories, though, were the real star(s). The Wire will unlikely ever be mentioned too often in the same breath as some of the other classics of it's era (like the Sopranos), but it probably deserves to be.

After one binge watches enough 'crime' series', "The Wire" comes as a bit of a revelation. This series has more 'reality' in one episode than an entire run of many of the series I've watched. How they were able to do this and how they got what appears to be massive co-operation to do this from many sources is a mystery to me but .... well, words, my words at least, do not, can not, begin to measure this series. It must be measured by the individual viewer and, like the people portrayed, it is what it is. That Royo, at least, did not get recognition for his role is beyond my understanding albeit there were many who stand out as actors here. And who could've guessed that that tall, skinny, hawk faced Reddick looked like that? It seems the more I like something, the fewer words I have to praise it other than to say that you ain't seen nuthin' yu ain't seen The Wire yo.

To everyone complaining that it was too dark, too violent, too much cursing, too much drug activity... WTF do you think happens in police work on a special detail made up of detectives from the homicide and NARCOTICS units? In B-MORE? C'mon, it was a cable show. If you want police lite, go find old episodes of CopRock somewhere. Maybe Moonlighting or at best, Miami Vice. Some of us appreciate amazing writing, gritty drama, and some of the most amazing acting in a police drama that I've ever seen. Idris Elba is a POWERHOUSE. Dominic West as McNulty is a wonderfully acted dichotomy of cop working hard yet with a not-so-perfect side. And you can't even question Michael K Williams as Omar Little. Damn, son. Poetry. One of the co-writers is a former Baltimore homicide detective. I'm pretty sure he has a good feel for how the city works. The creative staff is amazing. The show has slow points, but so does life and that kind of work, and the show isn't afraid to reflect that. Which makes it all the more realistic. If you can't appreciate it, move on. Your loss. The rest of us will feel all the more blessed for having seen this true work of creative genius.

The Wire is a gritty and gripping detective drama, which is widely considered to be one of the all-time best shows in this genre, as well as being one of the greatest television programs ever made. It was created and primarily written by David Simon, the renowned author and former crime reporter, who, because of his background, was able to impart an uncanny sense of realism to the series. The Wire was set and produced in Baltimore, Maryland, and its story line centers around the organization and function of the criminal drug trade in Baltimore, and the tragic way in which it has ravaged the city, and its beleaguered residents. The Wire consists of a total of sixty episodes, spanning five seasons, with a different emphasis for each season. Although the multifaceted drug trade represents the overarching focus of this series, each individual season assesses the manner in which this criminal enterprise impacts a specific operational area of the city of Baltimore. The first season of The Wire" examines the drug trade itself, the second season deals with the dysfunctional seaport system, the third season analyzes the corrupt city government and bureaucracy, the fourth season addresses the deteriorating school system, and the fifth and final season evaluates the unethical print news media. It brutally and realistically depicts the devastating effects that the criminal narcotic trade has had on the residents of inner city Baltimore, whose lives have been destroyed by the pervasive drug-related misery, despair, and hopelessness, which have now become endemic in this population. The Wire is characterized by insightful and brilliant writing, superb plot and character development, and absolutely spectacular acting performances, by its exceedingly talented ensemble cast. It definitely deserves the numerous awards and accolades which it has received over its five-year run. The Wire is a truly outstanding television series, which is riveting, moving, and emotional, and it merits an unequivocal five-star rating, along with a very strong recommendation.

Wired was so well done, I felt like I took a reality walk through another world. The Baltimore projects, The characters evolved with such subtle sensitivity that even in the midst a murdering rampage--the element of honor can  exist...different views of varying moral standards. I freakin love it. And it killed me when you know who got shot.  Stellar acting. Seamless, reality driven writing...I could go with 5 stars but I'd have to have some kind of awakening.

I was one of the many many ppl that heard of the hype surrounding the wire and chose not to watch.  I can tell you years later that it was a mistake.  Once you get past season 1, which is slow but very necessary to get you invested in the characters you will be following through 5 years of episodes, the stories seem to flow in an organic fashion.  There is action yes but there is also alot of moves that are made in one episode that will pay off in later episodes.  As the series is no longer broadcast, it does benefit from binge watching.  The characters suck you in both the good and the bad. If you can stick through all 5 seasons, the final season really pays off and bring the whole series full circle to a conclusion.

I personally found just about every moment I managed to sit through some of the most uninspired "storytelling" I've ever suffered through. No particularly interesting characters to care about, tons of stereotypes, endless contrived dialog to the point it's hard to tell if the show is a parody or not. Hard to tell the difference between on episode from the next; cops chasing drug dealers, drug dealers talkin' gangsta, and some variations on that - for five long and pointless seasons.

I live near Baltimore so I had a special local interest, but I think anyone who likes a good cop show would find it very entertaining.

Free yourself from distractions, use headphones and binge.  This is fast street action presented through audio and acting, with coded messages,  nuanced conversations, facial micro-expressions and a studly score creating the drama.  With dozens of well cast characters and hundreds of moving parts, they get everything about the specific time, culture and technology where no artifice is required to keep you on the edge.  This is Baltimore before Martin O'Malley with racial tensions, drugs, guns and money, getting shaken by a moke named McNulty whose chief virtues are street smarts and stubbornness.  The cops and dealers are evenly matched man for man and the lines get blurred by personal relations and politics so you know the final score is going to be close, but teamwork beats top-down.

There are moral dilemmas and crises on both sides with players getting ground in the street chess (chess is also used as a potent metaphor).  Adjusting to a screenplay that constantly reaches for reality instead of entertainment takes time and concentration but is harder to stop than cocaine. This is easier to watch if you are used to black and white movies with subtitles.

There is a good reason that The Wire is in the conversation for the best television series of all time.  It is politically astute, rich with fully developed characters, and very well plotted. As dark as it is with an underlying tone of hopelessness, there is enough wit and at least one unique character to root for.  Unlike shows such as The Sopranos and Breaking Bad, this show does not manipulate one into rooting for truly evil characters.  While there are sympathetic "bad guys" and despicable cops and public officials, this show has a strong moral core.  Each of the five seasons focuses on a different aspect of a major city (Baltimore), but characters carry over from season to season.  This first season focuses on how the drug enterprise leads to the deterioration of civil society both in terms of the dealers and their community as well as the law enforcement, legal, and political cultures. The drug enterprise pervades all five seasons, but is the entire focus of the first season.  This is an engrossing show that is in no way a "guilty pleasure," it is television at its best.  Worth all of the accolades it has drawn.

The Wire remains as good today as when it first aired. It is just as well written and acted as it was in 2002. Yes I was one of the few who watched it during its initial run.

The only difference is that at the time there was NOTHING else like it nor had there been previously. Today that is not true. Without The Wire modern long form storytelling as is common today might not have arrived for years. Shows like Game of Thrones and Breaking Bad have gotten people used to the idea that a TV show CAN tell a complete story with a beginning, middle and end but at the time The Wire aired the majority of TV shows only told one hour stories with very little character development. They were made so people could watch any episode from any season in any order without feeling lost, the show would reset every hour: Law and Order, CSIJAGNCIS (oh it's not the same show, sorry) didn't have character or story development.

Enter The Wire and a new era of television. Now days TV IS where we get longform storytelling, the movies are, for the most part, slam bang spectacle where this months superhero charges into the abyss. Don't get me wrong I love superhero movies but two hours is not enough time to tell a deep story. A whole season of Television spread out over multiple years that gives writers room to have character development.

Events from the first season resonate through all the way to the last episode. The wire is a masterpiece of writing acting directing peer storytelling in a visual form. This was a story that was meant to go for five seasons. The main character is the city of Baltimore the residents,  the cops, the criminals, the addicts, politicians, schools and let's not forget city Hall, the tell the city's story. There are no good and bad guys just a LOT of shades of gray.
Completely lives up to the hype. This show is so real and still manages to be entertaining. Awesomely done!

Hard core and enlightening all in one.  I got turned on to this series by Adam Plantinga in his book 400 Things Cops Know (great book BTW).  This series uses the Baltimore PD as its backdrop for some very interesting, gritty stories.  Created by David Simon, author of "Homicide: A Year on the Killing Streets" (1991), the series benefits from his 12 years working as a reporter for the Baltimore Sun's City Desk.

Is it relevant?  Well, if you're entertaining support for or joining BLM you should watch this series and perhaps read 400 Things Cops Know before making your move.  The world isn't always what it seems or what you may believe it or want it to be.

A waste of good acting and compelling cinematography.  Most people who rely heavily on profanity and expletive lack communication skills.  Faithfully copying such lamed and limited language into a script results in dialog that has the same shortcomings.  Only the most basic ideas can be expressed, and inefficiently at that.  No wonder these episodes drag.  Script writers really ought to study Shakespeare's plays.  All the characters in those plays, noble or evil, comic or tragic, ancient or young, mundane or magical, had lines to speak that revealed their natures and passions almost from their first words.  Shakespeare was the ultimate efficiency expert when it came to writing dialog, and every playwright since can learn from him.  For that matter, so can novelists, speech writers, and the folks who write commercials.  Especially that last bunch.

A slow-moving plot, a dialog liberally dependent on a torrent of common obscenities, a parade of mostly unlikable characters, all predisposed me to view this TV series negatively. On the plus side, it seemed that the depiction of the lower-class African-American subculture including its particular dialect was quite realistic--or, alternatively, that it was faithfully based on the broader society's biased expectations regarding this subculture, replete with two-dimensional stereotypes. Ultimately, this series left me cold because I have seen too many films and videos with a drug-dealer theme. This series, like many other portrayals of the drug subculture, end up indirectly, gradually, subliminally, to romanticize the life of the people--dealers and cops--who depend on it. 1 star.

When these episodes first aired back in 2002, this was the absolute high-water mark in cop-show realism, with the guts to show things as they are, and none of the saccharine BS you get in all the weenie attempts from ABC, CBS, and NBC. The Wire did as much as the Sopranos to cement HBO's position at the pinnacle of TV production. Even after all the years everybody has had since 2002 to try to copy and catch up, the Wire is still among the greatest achievements in the genre.

Crime and justice has been great television over the years. HBO was the front runner in original series way before the internet streaming businesses ever thought of a consumer concept to develop groundbreaking material..Sorry to say but for the most part, HBO/Time Warner hit it hard and heavy in 1997 with my first addiction "OZ" and followed closely with one of the best shows on anywhere in the world with "The Sopranos" (1999-2007)...Now with The Wire, it has a gritty cast and a realistic backdrop of the criminal drug trade of West Baltimore, MD, Unfortunately, through the first three episodes, most of these detectives-out-on-the-streets to shut down the drug trade in the city's housing projects has a lot of same and tried approaches along with some in the Baltimore PD unit going a bit above and beyond that ultimately let's the dealers score some judicial victories...Lot of OZ alumni casted bringing their former experiences with Tom Fontana and they try to work this material and it just seems to fall short of the big bang endings and payoffs that HBO fans are used to...

This is the best police show I have ever seen. (Homicide: Life on The Streets) being a close second.  The character development has depth for all characters presented.  The complexity of development is not limited to the "good guys".  In fact, the thing that makes this series so great.is that.the bad guys are every bit as interesting as the police. But they are not one demensional and begins to see them as something other than criminals. Even when the bad guys are caught you feel some empathy with some of them. The law enforcement characters are equally complex and very much have issues with each others, not just the people they are chasing.  And then there is the political interaction between politicians and the police that highlights the divisions between those who are supposedly on the same side.  The writing is spectacular.
Idris Elba is amazing in this.

Perhaps the best TV show of all times.  Cast and acting are superb.  Season 1 depicts a dark, gritty story about the drug trafficking in Baltimore and the police attempts to deal with it and build a case against one of the key drug dealers.  Also shows the negative effect of the culture of the police and government and how it interferes with enforcement of the law and solving the drug problem in the city.  Very realistic tv drama that explains the difficulty of solving the drug problem, which is part of a larger systemic problem in the city.

Plus I hate it when they release season three of a show but you can't see season 1 &2. 99% of the time, I will not watch out of sequence. An incredible show, season 1 may be the best season of TV drama ever aired. The characters and story arcs are true to real life to a greater extent than I have ever seen in a cinematic experience, while at the same time the plot is is perhaps the most involved and captivating I have seen. This show could easily be documenting real events with its grit, deeply flawed characters, and lack of any true good guys and bad guys. This show has tons of valuable lessons buried in each episode for the attentive and engaged viewer, and is an incredibly rewarding show to watch. Everyone should watch the first season. I've been shocked to see some negative reviews, but barring personal experiences that would make this show uncomfortable to watch, there really aren't any legitimate reasons not to find it objectively good in some way, there's just so much going for this show.

I watched this when it first came out and HBO and loved it, and watching it again confirmed my initial reaction. Save for some changes in technology, The Wire could have been released today and be as relevant now as it was then. The theme of crime is woven into all 5 seasons with the ghettos of Baltimore serving as the front lines in the war against it. What makes The Wire so special is that each issue or group represented in any season is given brutally fair and humane treatment. There hasn't been a series as honest as The Wire in the history of television. And to add butter cream icing to this delicious cake of a series, the writers have seen fit to explore crimes' relationship to public education in the inner city, urban politics, the judicial system, and the role of the media and how technology affects it. Must see TV at it's very best.

The Wire didn't fully hit its stride until Season 1 Episode 4 in my opinion but after that there was no doubt that it was the absolute best that television ever had to offer (until Breaking Bad which is the only series that ever approached the same level of brilliance).

The place where The Wire beats out Breaking Bad is in the depth of acting: the numerous brilliant actors and actresses who made this one of the absolute high points that TV will ever reach.  Every character - both major and minor - is acted as if the actors' life depended on it and maintaining a continuous story arch that never ceases to fascinate over the course of a 5 year run is an achievement that has only been matched (but not exceeded) by Breaking Bad.

I have little doubt that even David Simon and Edward Burns were completely surprised at the success of their efforts.  At times the story line had to be changed.  Perhaps the show's most memorable character "Omar" "(Michael K Williams) was scheduled to be in only 3 episodes as I recall but his character was so wildly popular that the show had to be modified to make him a major character throughout the series.

I remember posting incessantly on "The Wire'" fan board on the HBO site when the show was first airing and one episode especially (I will not tell you which it is) hitting me so hard that I could not make it to work the next day.

I cannot imagine drama on film ever reaching a higher level.  If it ever does I hope I am still alive to see it.  For the time being I think high end television has taken over conventional 2-3 hour films as the point where visual drama reaches its highest level.

But no matter how many 6/5 star series hit the airwaves (Breaking Bad, Justified, Deadwood) it is very difficult to imagine anything surpassing The Wire.

It was the best that anybody had ever seen in its day and it is an absolute "must watch" for anybody who is serious about film.  Even going back to Tarkovsky and Bergman, The Wire is at least on the same level.

An unrepeatable masterpiece that you absolutely should not miss if you have not yet seen it.  As a college professor I can attest to the fact that as of mid 2016 the vast majority of my 18-22 year old students have not ever even heard of it.

David Chase's magnum opus starts off with a bang. Season 1 sets a magnificent table. Crime-ridden, dope infested Bmore, cynical jaded, careerist cops and embittered Murder Police, trying to clear cases and keep civilians safe, and a cast of gangsters that Tony Montana and Vito Corleone would admire. The Wire entered pop culture and the best tag lines are heard today. The dialogue is straight off the streets, the characters  are richly drawn and the sub-plots are a joy to follow. The good guys aren't all good and the bad guys aren't all bad, just like in real life. Every character gets some screen time. The parallel universes the cops and robbers occupy make a great juxtaposition. Both camps have to worry about chain of command, below-average workers, pressure to perform, and internal politics...oh, yeah, and money. How they handle their business is one of the joys of watching The Wire.

The Wire has very good acting and displays a picture of detectives trying to close drug and crime cases.  Upper management in the Police Department prefer cases not to go to far and want only to catch not the leaders of the various crime operations.  There is a single unit of detectives  that feel differently.  The leader of the unit is a LT.  He is consistently getting called to managements office to be asked what the hell they are doing going after politicians when they are involved.
Realistic actors and a compelling story line.  That's all I need to keep tuning in.
Entertaining and enlightening with rich characters and unfortunately, the real world conflicts we all deal with as we trade our beliefs for pragmatic actions.

Simply put, The Wire is the best dramatic series in the history of television.  A thoughtful five part arc that covers the decline of America's urban landscape in all its aspects - season one focuses on the drug wars and lays out the corrosive effects that this as had on the entire urban fabric.  Written by ex-Baltimore Sun writer David Simon the series is an al a clef of the fight for territory and the effects on citizens and players alike,  The police department is shown no longer policing, but being an occupying army trying to fight an always morphing enemy.  The show stars Dominec West  as Detective Jimmy McNulty, an alcoholic booze hound centered mainly on himself but who has a nack for making sense out of complicated puzzles.  Wendall Peirce is his partner, Detective Moreland aka Bunk.  Every character rings true and the situations are drawn from actual crimes in Baltimore - both in the drug wars and the political realm.  The overall effect is a stunning picture of how bureaucracies fail and how durg money corrupts everything it touches absolutely.
Given recent attention to policing in the US, and Baltimore in particular the show is as relevant now as it was in 2002 when it debuted.  It is not to be missed.

We recently started rewatching, beginning with the pilot. It's amazing how organically all the exposition takes place. It has almost none of the clumsiness that you find with every TV show that came before it. Patience and confidence are apparent at nearly every step in the storytelling.

The audience is trusted to figure out what's going on, or to live comfortably with the uncertainty until it makes sense for the story points to be revealed. The characters are real, three dimensional human beings with relatable motivations and flaws. In some ways, it does nearly the impossible. You find yourself rooting for the "good guys" and the "bad guys" all in the same episode because they're all such interesting, sympathetic characters in spite of the awful things they may do in "the Game."

David Simon's The Wire - Season 1 - is the beginning of an epic work set in Baltimore MD as the 21st century dawns.  Society is breaking down, values are shifting, and we're drawn into a world comprised of people who have been written off  by society and those who prey on them: drug dealers, snitches, thieves, politicians, police.  Life is cheap and the atmosphere is poisonous; lives and careers are made and lost in a welter of petty feuds, overarching ambition and naked greed.  No good deed goes unpunished; no one emerges unscathed.  Brilliant writing, acting, directing, editing, photography all coming together.  Not easy to watch, but definitely worth it, imo.

Why did they ever take this off the air? The acting alone merits 5 Stars. This is real life, the struggle between Law and Lawless is a vast area of Gray and this show brings out the Gray perfectly. All of us who can walk down the streets at night and sleep safe in our beds have no idea about the war going on each and every night. This show speaks to the fact that many of our young can not find jobs, hope or a future so slinging drugs brings home money to pay the day to day bills...but at a price....no one dies of old age down on these streets. The Police have to cross the thin gray line to even slow down the drug traffic and pay for it with their lives or careers. The show touches on so many of our present social issues each episode could come out or today's headlines. Well Done! It's a shame it's gone.

I'm not sure why I didn't watch this series when it was on TV. I thought it wouldn't interest me but now I see that it is just the kind of drama that I like. There certainly is a lot of adult themes including language, sex, and violence which I would not be comfortable watching with some family members. Mostly I binge watched the entire first season, although it was broken into just few episodes each session. There is something so satisfying about binge watching.

I found the story line intriguing. Even though the cop versus criminals theme is pretty common, I found this different enough to keep me watching. I also like several of the criminal characters and don't want to see them killed off. This wasn't a series that any of my friends talked about. The only reason I started watching it was that I didn't have access to regular TV and was looking for something to binge watch. I remembering seeing The Wire on a list of the best TV series so I thought I would give it a try. Now I am so glad that I did.

As a fan of "Crime/Cop Shows", I have very high standards for production quality, acting, directing and most of all, realism, and true to life drama. This is one of the better shows in this genre, and has a very loyal following even now,(2016) as well as it did when it was made.(2002)
Some reviewers have stated that this show is very real to life. I have to disagree. Being a person that has lived the lives depicted in this genre, I know what is realistic and what is "Hollywood". My major complaint is that this show is good, it has real situations and people, but then the Director seems to have to reach for more, and go over the top, to get his point across. IMO, this was not necessary, as the realism and the acting got the point across. The added "Hollywood BS" (HBS), tends to make a great scene, just a good scene.
I hope that Season Two continues to impress me.

Welcome to the world of inner city drug dealing, not a pretty sight. It's TV, so there is the presence of over dramatizing at times, but the show is graphic about what happens in that world. Anybody that pays attention to the news, is aware of what parts of Baltimore are like today, but that's only a small part of Baltimore. The show is riveting at times, to the point of forgetting that it's a TV show. I like the show a lot, and have enjoyed all of the episodes, but like anything, it's not for everybody. I would recommend watching an episode, and see what you think. You just might get hooked. Hope this provides some insight. Happy viewing.

PS: Omar, one of the characters in the show (Michael Kenneth Williams), was Chalky White, in Boardwalk Empire.

If your favorite word is the "F" word, you will feel right at home with the writing for this show.  In fact, you will never be allowed to forget you are at home.  You will feel so welcome you may want to crawl into the television and nestle up to the brutally-base characters depicted here.  In their attempt to be authentic, the writers F-this, F-that, F-life, F-breakfast cereal and F-french toast too.  An F word variation is trotted out ever third word or s every third sentence or so.  When are writers going to realize that gritty language is not a sign of intelligent life?

One good thing about it, the single show I watched made me want to swear a lot less.

Probably the most unrealistic cop show I've every watched.  I struggled through the first two episodes and can't stomach the rest.  What really surprises me is that the City of Baltimore PD actually allows the actors to wear their patches and portray themselves as Baltimore PD officers.  After watching, I can understand the very poor public perception of police officers these days because some people don't understand that this is hollywood and not the real thing so they form an even stronger hatred towards officers after watching all the corrupt and frankly stupid things these guys do and how it's swept under the rug by supervisors.  Thanks again Hollywood for helping to paint a poor perception of our officers.

While it was mistakenly promoted as a crime procedural show, what The Wire is ACTUALLY about is a realistic and scathing portrayal of Reagan's misguided and dysfunctional "War on Drugs" and the damage it has done over the last 30 years to every city in America. Just the fact that David Simon's series officially ended on HBO in 2008 and continues to gather an ever-increasing cult following by the passing year should tell you all you need to know about the show's relevance. Simon was a crime writer for the Baltimore Sun for 15 years, working the police beat before writing the show, and basically created a parallel narrative over 5 years in the city of Baltimore portraying the corruption of an entire system which makes the problem of drugs in inner cities worse, not better. Several of the show's actors are not in fact actors at all, but actual former drug dealers that were pulled off Baltimore's streets and given a second chance by being on the show. Many now have programs to benefit Baltimore's inner city kids in various ways, and you can find interviews with them on the web.

From season to season The Wire exposes the problem from a slightly different angle, covering: the street-level dealers; the ports; the municipal government; the school system; and finally the press- showing how the flaws in each of these elements contribute to a costly and destructive system that keeps the very problem the drug war has portended to eliminate in place. If you are looking for a crime procedural in which you move from problem to resolution in each episode, you should go back to your NYPD Blue as this is NOT the show for you. Most of the heartbreaking problems in The Wire never get solved, anymore than they have been in real life. With stellar writing and seasoned character actors, you could not get a better near-biography of every U.S. city since the 1980s. It continues to spark a dialogue with thousands of new viewers even 8 years after the show went off air for a lot of really good reasons.

If you search online you will find a ton of blogs, YouTube videos and interviews, and very active comment threads discussing the topics brought to light in The Wire. Simon's own blog has some incisive commentary about things that happened while shooting the series, including multiple attempts by the actual mayor of Baltimore (after whom the mayoral character of seasons 3-5 was closely written) to intimidate Simon into shutting down the show altogether. Furthermore, in 2013, President Obama himself invited David Simon to the White House to discuss massive reforms of the "war on drugs." Perhaps one day the discussion The Wire incites will lead to real social change.

Not my usual preference, but after so many referrals from.friends, I did binge watch this and found it to be compelling.  I'm certainly looking forward to season 2.  The only jarring note, for me, is the scenery chewing, over acting by the "lead actor" in the role of McNulty.....Given the prominence of Baltimore's problems in today's news, I found this series to be eye-opening and heart wrenching.  The official complicity in keeping the drug trade in business as long as it stays "contained" is a seething indictment of the status quo.....money and politics.......ambition and office politics....desperate poverty and the tragedies of addiction......misguided (if "successful") entrepreneurs....

You know how it can be with streaming TV nowadays...often you sit through show after show mainly out of 'habit' more than anything...almost like spending time with your mate 24/7, because that's just 'what you do'...to change or try something different would require effort.  lol.  Well I find that's how it is for me with certain streaming TV.  The Wire would fall into that category.

I lasted through the end of Season One but finally had to admit to myself that I was watching the show out of habit, and not because I necessarily found it 'compelling'.

Overall the episodes felt pretty much the same.  I also had a hard time keeping the character names straight, and understanding how the various gangs did or did not work together or certain of their members overlap.  Who was 'playing' who?  At the end of Season One one of the major players gets killed and I was confused as to 'why' and who it was who 'gave him up'.

As for the realistic aspect of the show, in general it felt pretty good though there were a few scenes and lines that felt very unrealistic to me.  I also didn't buy the fact that supposedly none of the drug dealers had any clue that er...what's his name... the guy who would snitch to the cops for a price and who was always pushing around the 'Whitey Sale' shopping cart...I just didn't buy the fact that he could sit in the back of the cop car....and within eyeshot of the drug dealers...and nobody every noticed him interacting with the cops...nobody caught on to him?  A true snitch like him would have had to be way more careful and stealth.

I've decided to move on to a different streaming show and not watch any more of The Wire. That said, a few great actors IMHO on the show:

the Italian guy who plays the politician vying for the office of Mayor

the black guy who was like the 'Lieutenant' or something and who was the mastermind behind setting up the 'Amsterdam' zone

the black guy who headed up one of the gangs..I forget his name but he was the one who in the very beginning of Season One, gets let out of prison.  He's really great.

the young black kid who's one of the dealers...and almost looks more like a thugged-out girl at times...who has this very 'street' hip-hop way of talking...I get a real kick out of them...

the white cop who we generally only see on the beat....he's bald ..maybe early 40s with a round face.  His bald head, the way he carries himself, the way he talks...I could TOTALLY see him as an undercover cop in NYC.  He embodies your stereotypical macho undercover cop.
If you know Baltimore, this is the show for you.  Keeps your interest every minute.

One of the best crime procedural shows ever. It won several awards over several years. Great stories and great acting. The title "The Wire" comes from the fact that early on in the series, the detectives in the show figure out that in order to make criminal cases against the leaders of the outfits running drugs on the streets of Baltimore, they will need audio wiretapping surveillance to connect them with the lower level criminals actually working the streets. The wiretapping efforts are aided by some new advances in electronics technology but there is still much of a cat and mouse game between the cops and bad guys. But most of the show's action is still on the streets. The show also takes a wide look at all the players in the system having a stake including the judges, lawyers, prosecutors, cops, City Hall, state and local legislature, federal law enforcement (FBI), etc. The story line is rich, complex, and real-world. I can say the same for all of the show's seasons. Well done.

One of my favorite shows of all time. I have recently started to watch the show again from the beginning hoping that reality would nto tarnish my memory. So far, watching the show has been as satisfying as the first time. The show is so nuanced that on a second viewing you are able to pick up on many things that passed you by the first time.

The show refuses to deal in stereotypes or pretend that there are simple solutions to complex problems. No one is all good and even bad guys can do good things. It asks tough questions, Baltimore is protrayed as a drug ridden, violent place yet the writers clearely love Baltimore and the people of Baltimore who are trying to survive, trying to make it a better palce inspite of all of the obstacles.

If you want story where everyone is happy, where the good guys are good and the bad guys are bad, and where the problems are tied up in a neatly tied bow, this show is not for you. 0If you are interested in understanding inner city problems through the eyes of all the players, this is the show for you.

Truly a wonderful television experience.  Too often TV shows either lose their continuity or get boring trying to keep it consistent.  The Wire does an excellent job of keeping that continuity while bringing in new characters and perspectives to make it gripping.

I'm sure this may have been discussed before about "The Wire" but I'll tell you my thoughts on the show. I've never been in law enforcement but it seems the show is very realistic is the way it portrays both sides of crime and prevention. Maybe the most realistic "TV" portrayal I've seen. Most of the time you get the perspective only from the law enforcement side, in "The Wire" you get the perspective from both the Police and the criminal side. From the first episode you begin to know the characters from both the Law enforcement and the Criminal side equally. You get to see a glimpse into the daily lives of both sides and what causes the situation that they are in. The first season focuses on a new Police team brought together to break up and arrest a local Drug organization. It is definitely an interesting take in a Police Drama, You actually begin to feel sorry for some of the people caught up on the drug dealing side because you see why they do what they do and circumstances that lead them there. The series also shows the frustration and cooperation or lack of cooperation from the Law enforcement side between the different departments, not much sugar coated here.  We are getting ready to start season 2 and looking forward to see the next part of the story and if it holds up as well as Season 1.

This show is wonderful because it's gritty and realistic. In this 1st season we meet some of Baltimore's Finest led by a nuisance cop name Jimmy. He rounds up some misfit cops and together they plan to take down drug kingpin Avon Barksdale (might have spelled that wrong). We get a look at the inner workings of the BPD, and life in the drug game and it's not just from the gangsters prospective. We see the effects of drugs and violence that goes on in not just Baltimore, but nearly every ghetto in America. There's the young kids in poverty from families torn apart by drugs, we see an addicts journey through life. It's a very in your face show with no happy endings. Yet, it's an adventure you'll never forget.

I abhor violence, but never found it or the nudity too graphic or gratuitous. The story lines are intriguing, the cinematography engaging and the acting flawless. Everyone involved with The Wire should be extremely proud of what they accomplished. In a just world, it would have won multiple awards. Disappointing that it didn't.

I started out with the intention of watching all 5 seasons of this depressing show, but only got through the first 3 episodes. Yes, it's got a great cast, with many of the stars going on to do award-winning series after The Wire.  So it was fun seeing familiar faces. The trouble is, The Wire is just another cop show that tries too hard to be hip and savvy.  It took at least a couple fo episodes to get up to speed on who in the hell is snitching on whom, and to wade through the thick jargon that seems practically like a foreign language.  The stories aren't compelling enough for me to care, and the characters are so hard-assed, it's hard to care about them, either. I can sort of see why the show garnered the awards it did, but since the Wire, cop shows have come a long way, and are just much better.

Taut, complex crime drama and social commentary stacked on one full plate. Characters develop over time, lending a quality of reality seldom found in television drama. Depictions of police work, criminal organizations, and the politics that plague both are riveting and realistic. Eminently binge-worthy. Additionally, the primary focus changes with each season, depicting different facets of corruption and the ways it weaves itself into every level of contemporary culture.

"The Wire" is not at all what I thought it would be! I can't wait to watch the next four seasons!

  With all that said and what I know off all of the above, which may be little, Maybe not, either way, in my opinion this series is the closest to the truth about one facet of American life that we are either a part of, or are willing to stick our heads in a hole in the ground and act ignorant when confronted. This is America in the 21 century, coming to your neighborhood shortly. We as society are all responsible for creating this monster that will destroy us, If for no other reason, for allowing it to happen.

Some interesting characters and a good cast, but writing has too many cop drama cliches. Most characters are full of rage for no reason, cops dislike everyone but their partner and all Feds, cop bosses and politicians are incompetent or corrupt. Alcoholism reigns in the PD--and of course, the central character is a loose cannon.

Cast out of the Dirty Harry mold, 40 years later.

That said, The Wire offers an extensive  inside look at the ghetto heroin trade not seen before.

But the theme of The Wire is even if you're smart and work hard, it doesn't matter. The game is rigged at every point. You can't win. Hopefully, this will change in later seasons.

The Wire is arguably one of the most well written dramas in the past few decades. Just an incredibly riveting series that set so many bars for television shows. On the surface you can call it a police drama, but it is definitely way more than that. The uniqueness of the series is how they treat both sides of the coin - the police side of the coin - their frustrations and bureaucracies all played out beautifully. Then the criminal side of the coin - the drug traffickers and kingdom - featuring very rich, deep characterization that goes way beyond the knee jerk portrayal of 'thugs' and 'punks'.

I watched it during its original run, but I recently turned a co-worker on to the series. I am re-watching the episodes along with his fresh eyes and it still holds up strong. I absolutely recommend this to anyone able or willing.

Wow - if only I'd known back when this garbage was being excreted, I coulda been a contender, a screenwriter. All I would have needed to do for a 240,000 word screenplay covering all characters would be insert F*** and its variations for 40 percent of the time, then go on vacation to write the rest of the work. I put this junk down for several months, then opened it up again, and inside of three minutes, there it was again. Over and over and over, like a two year old excited he can say the Naughty Word. Hey, Marines - don't worry, hey you, black belt, hey you, MMA fighter - forget training, hey, Yazidi women being grabbed and raped and sold into sexual slavery by bovine hellspawn, you didn't have to be sold into slavery, all any of you had to do was shout F*** over and over and the armies of evil would flee in terror. The F word makes you tough, didn't you know that?. I've been watching movies and TV shows for many decades, including many R rated, so I'm not prissy about the use of this word, it's just such a ludicrous, juvenile substitute for quality, dramatic writing. I don't care what these so-called 'writers' have left to offer, I'm deleting this excretion from my watch list after this reaction posts. Good riddance. The Wire Season 1

One of the most realistic shows ever made on crime, race relations and the war on drugs. Even if it is a bit dated (using payphones and beepers), its themes and issues still ring very loud and true today. This has to be one of the best takes on the classic "cops and robbers" or "law and order" type of show because of its very raw nature, along with an amazing cast and superb screenwriting. Definitely recommend this show to anyone interested in policy, racism and the inner workings of a city.

This is one of the greatest TV police dramas of all times.  It's authentic portrayal of inner city Baltimore and the inner working of both the drug trade and the bureaucracies that exists in law enforcement departments are second to none.  If you can get beyond your own prejudices and view the characters as the director intended them to fit their mold, you will realize that the story as a whole is incredible.

This show is gut-wrenching and relentlessly raw, but I think it tries to present a vision of poverty and race relations in America that many of us rarely see in a way that doesn't preach, that keeps it messy, just like life.  No one is completely good or completely bad.  This is Shakespearean tragedy in our time.  I thought I was done with cops and robbers shows, but this takes it to a completely different level, and well worth the binge watching.  I did have to take a break because it became too heartbreaking to see the desperate lives of the boys in the 'jects.  How sad that in real life they can't just 'take a break'.  Will someone tell me there are glimmers of hope and redemption, or is the show just relentlessly depressing?

I got into gritty, dark crime dramas like The Shield, SouthLAnd, Breaking Bad or Low Winter Sun and always wanted to check out The Wire. I finally got around to doing that & it's a great, realistic show.  In fact, it's so realistic that it almost borderlines too much on the inner workings and intricacies of crime fighting in inner city, urban settings, and the lives of those who uphold the law & investigate to those who break it and try to get rich or die trying.  The complicated relationships and backgrounds to the characters are richly woven and brought believably to the screen in this ensemble cast show.

Not the first time I have watched this series. Granted white liberals love this show and I suppose I'm one. But as a crime drama it is one of the most complex. Writing, directing, acting I can't find any holes. The cast is phenomenal. So many of these actors turn up in other series these days. It's virtually a who's who of superb actors (not just from the U.S.) from the highly experienced to the young first timers. Some of the actors weren't even actors before this series began.  The first season may seem dated these days given the kinds of technologies we have today. (Yes there was a device called a beeper.)  The thing I enjoy most is that it takes on the entire conglomerate of crime, law and order along with the political system and gives us an unexpected view of what the reality is (or was in Baltimore or still is) sans the moralizing you get from other crime dramas. Watch it. See if you don't hooked.
Great show! It's probably in my all-time top 10 favorites; definitely in my top 20.

The Wire is highly lauded and deservedly so; what kept me away was not having cable.  I also thought the theme of the program might be too dark for me.  Since it was available on Amazon Prime, I decided to finally see what everyone was talking about.  I love the humanness of the characters.  They are vividly constructed, written and acted. It's actually the non-law enforcement, non-judicial characters who interest me the most, altho all of the characters are well-written & well-acted and non-stereotypical with the exception of some minor female characters.  I actually think about these characters after viewing the program and I have never done this with any other TV show including MM.  The show is a living breathing example of organizational behavior. It is dynamic, it is real, it is intelligent and it is sad.

The character development and growth are immense, the story engaging, the acting is seamless. The only thing I warn anyone who wants to pick up their own copy is be ready. You get to experience this show for the first-time only once, and when you do... The love will grow.

One of the best shows ever written, the characters are real, the writing is amazing, the dialog so natural that there is no sense that you are watching a drama, instead it feels as if you are riding right along with them. The writers flesh the characters out to such a degree that we feel as if we know them, like they are our intimate friends and family, like all families the good people have thier flaws and the bad people have thier deft moments of compassion and self realization that makes them human and not a one dimensional television character Indris Elba is amazing, as is the entire cast, all in all this production was flawless. If you have not seen the wire, you have not seen what possibilities television can hold.

"The Wire" was an honest representation of what is happening in our world today. It shows that Law enforcement, political officials, and the judicial system, hold civilians to the laws while they don't hold themselves to the laws. "The Wire" shows the truth about young people trying for a much needed education. This need becomes almost impossible to achieve because of the politicians compelling law enforcement to break the rules. And subsidize the budgets by compelling law enforcement to bring in more revenue such as issuing more summonses often for minor offenses. This goes on while law enforcement, political officials, and the judicial system cover themselves from paying for summonses.
It's really a good show and alot more a curate than other cop shows.

This show rolls deep. You'd be hard pressed to find a show that is as thought provoking, well written, and as realistic as the wire. It is a true indictment of the so-called "war on drugs", and a microscopic view into a world that politicians think they can deal with, cops live and die trying to control, and kids are born into with little hope of escaping.

Completely brilliant first season of one of the best series ever on television.
A Baltimore homicide detective instigates for a deeper investigation into the city's drug kingpins. This makes him the target of his superiors who are more interested in image politics than real police work. "The Wire" also delves into the violent inner-workings of the drug trade, presenting the criminals as three-dimensional characters
Police procedural, crime thriller, character comedy, journalistic expose.
The first season of "The Wire" works as a stand-alone, self-contained narrative. However, once you have gotten involved with these characters (on both sides of the law) it will be impossible for you not to continue on with the subsequent seasons. (And--spoiler alert!--Season 4 might be even better.)

Hands down the best show ever. I have recommended The Wire to literally dozens of people, and all have come back with the same opinion, "It's amazing!". The characters, the interweaving storylines, the lack of network TV bull. You will never watch another cop show again without it feeling silly and unrealistic compared to The Wire. Law and Order, CSI and all the rest will seem like they were made for children after watching all 5 seasons of this show. Complex? Yes. Difficult to follow? Not at all. Deep characters? All of them, but not silly overcharacterization you'd find on network TV, they all seem real and most are based on real people. It may take a couple of episodes to really get into it, but I guarantee after 4 episodes you'll be hooked and you'll be sad it ends after season 5. Not because it's unsatisfying, but you'll feel so invested into so many characters it's hard to see them go. Almost every aspect of the dark side of modern society is touched on, but without any preachy editorializing. It's just there in all its grayness and ambiguity for the viewer to decide right and wrong, good and evil.

The Wire season 1 is one of the best seasons of any TV show that I have ever watched.  The first season gives you an inside look at the inner workings of the Baltimore drug trade as well as the police department that is tasked with policing them.  One drug case is played out through the entire season which provides incredibly in-depth case details and characters.  A lot of shows that focus on different cases in each show are not able to provide such a full look at a high level drug case as it plays out.  The show does a great job developing unique characters that fit right in to the storyline.

One of the nice things about being able to watch a show in bulk is you are willing to watch more than just the first episode. If we had watched this on TV one week at a time we may have given up. It starts out a little slow with quite a few characters to try to learn. It took us about 3 episodes to become hooked and we enjoyed the full season. Lots of critical acclaim for this show and for good reasons. The acting is not super outstanding but the story line and characters are what really pull it together. Not often in live you actually feel bad for the drug dealers.

Most cop shows just show the cop side of things. This series shows both sides of the picture which really adds to to the grittiness of live on the streets. Of course everyone drinks their troubles away, there is various bits of drug use, nudity and language but this is from HBO so you probably already knew that.

Parts are not super realistic of course. Every single person squeals their tires when driving. Um, not the best way to stay under the radar when following someone. They follow one car length back so both cars stay in camera frame. Sitting outside a house means just that, sitting directly outside the house with camera and binoculars in plain sight. Those who investigate crimes for a living will probably cringe in horror at a lot of these types of issues. You are going to have to look past all of that to enjoy the characters and the story line.
This is an in-your-face crime series that is about as real as it gets. This series reminds me of my previous favorite, The Shield. Five stars to both.

This is one gripping story which shows the brutality of the drug trade, where little guys are murdered daily to protect the bigger guys. It also shows how the tremendous amount of profit has corrupted the society, from the dealers themselves to their informants in the police department, correctional facilities, their lawyers, the whole justice system and politicians who take a piece of the pie. The turf wars, robbery, mutiny and betrayal seen in the series further engage the viewers and highlight the wretched power of quick big money has on people's minds. Throughout the show, you will also find characters stuck in a place where a choice has to be made between doing what they see as right, doing their best job or taking cues from the boss or other influential individuals in the organization with their very career on the line. Characters are complex, lots of times you can not say they are just good or bad. They are more likely to be somewhere in between, or switching frequently from one side to another just as in real life. Be warned, it has more gay / lesbian sex scene than hetero sex scene which may not be the taste of the majority audience.

Amazing writing, acting and story telling. Rarely have I ever seen a tv show with such realism and complexity. This show really rewards audiences that are looking for an intelligent, thought provoking drama involving relatable, recognizable and human characters. It is fascinating to see how this show weaves multiple storylines, relationships, vantage points and motivations into a cohesive whole. There are no easy answers or fixes here, but a compelling, gripping and emotionally honest examination of the war on drugs. There is so many layers and sophistication here, but the real trick is that everything seems so natural and organic. Truly exceptional stuff.

Everyone should see this series at least once.

I haven't been so excited for a TV show since I binge watched all three seasons of Luther. I was captivated by this world of drugs, a smart detective, a mission on a collision course with failure, intrigue, and tension all wrapped up in the urban jungle of the Baltimore Projects.

I started The Wire anticipating a hum drum cop show, like so many, but with a cast including the future James Bond runner up (betting odd put him in the forefront, now that we have a black US President, a black Bond isn't too far away) the brilliant Idris Elba of the afore mentioned Luther, I had to at least give this show a try and I have been hooked ever since. (I was disheartened to find him a bad guy, and a second tier one at that, but he ended up having a deliciously dark character with plenty of screen time!)

I have done about 13 episodes in 7 days, and while I am not super proud of the amount of time that is, I have also finished 2 books, my home teaching, and the church bulletin for Sunday, so I guess my time management isn't as abysmal as it looks (ahem Kitchen  yikes)!

The wire is completely captivating show. From the first episode I was wrapped up in the tension. It starts with a lone cop, played by Dominic Cooper - a familiar face which always helps for me - wanting to change the system up a little and actually make a difference in his city. Its an uphill battle and he slowly brings onboard other cops - Lance Reddick being another familiar face who seems to be in freaking everything on TV now days - until they are pulling him along a bit too. At the same time the tragic lives of young black kids growing up in the projects consumed by the power, money, and violence that has wrapped its tentacles around every facet of their lives, until they turn on each other, all for the sake of the game.

These two cultures collide in a slow and thoughtful war, a drama built as meticulously as the cops building their cases.
Conversations taped on wires, cloned pager numbers, cops camped out on rooftops, the monotony of police work captured and lived as we learn and delve into a few of the detectives lives. At the same time we see the other side, the lives of the young hoods corrupted by the older gangsters. Seduced by the glory. Its an in-depth study characters, but also a look at two companies, two organizations, and you almost respect the gangsters more than some of the backstabbing butt kissing cops.
The show isn't for the faint hearted. I was impressed that HBO was able to do a show without extreme amounts of graphic nudity (barely R rated) but the profanity and some of the crime scene photos are not for the faint hearted. Its a gritty portrayal of two gritty professions.

I loved almost every minute of this first season, and whats more it was done so well that the 13 episodes is a story all in its own. Its solid. I could leave the show alone and still have a satisfactory beginning middle and end, a perfect mini-series. I am almost reluctant to continue in case it turns into Dexter or The West Wing two brilliant shows that fizzled into repetitive clichd parodies of themselves after two or three seasons.
So while I cant yet speak for the rest of the show, Season 1 of The Wire is a masterpiece.
Scintillating! Intriguing! Suspenseful. Still watching. We are on Episode 10.

I was so interested that I purchased the boxed set as soon as possible.  Fortunately, I had the summer off because I could NOT stop watching it.  I have watched the entire series more than once again.  Even though I know what's going to happen, I always see something new on subsequent viewings.  When I came across The Wire on Amazon Prime, I couldn't resist checking it out .  I own every season of The Sopranos; we watched weekly on HBO and purchased each season as it became available, but I have not re-watched every episode of every season of The Sopranos.  The Wire is in a class by itself.

I am a fan of cop shows ever since Hill Street Blues. I like hard-nosed gritty police dramas and The Wire is definitely up there with the best of them. The characters start out in season one already very well developed and the relationships very well established. The show is filmed very well, and even though it clearly is influenced by many of its forerunners, the show has its own unique identity,slant and color palate on certain aspects of inner city police work for the time and place portrayed. (Baltimore in the wary 2000's) Many of the tropes used by the show's creators/writers are very familiar but with some added depth depicting life within a system that lacks the technology, manpower and political will to make a lasting difference other than provide a modicum of check and balence to the impoverished drug infested poverty of Baltimore's inert city projects.
  Many of the lead characters, both cops and thugs, seem to have an amount of appreciation, if not some empathy, for each other's situations and circumstance. This isn't a typical "Good Guys Vs. Bad Guys" type of cop show. The Wire shows some very human and sometimes complex sides to the cops and the thugs.

  One gets by watching this series that everybody has good and bad in them and that a lot of life just depends on which side of the line you happen to land.

I've only watched a few episodes into season 1. It will be interesting to see where the show goes. If it just repeats the same tropes over and over again in a formulaic way, or whether new tropes emerge while old ones fade out. Hopefully the perspectives of the characters grow and evolve and can eventually help viewers gain an insight to an aspect of humanity.

Good  television series makes people think. This show has made me think a little bit in its first few episodes. I take that as s promising sign that The Wire is not just another distraction from life but another tool, another perspective on life...

A tense look at the inner city turmoil of baltimore, from every possible pertinent angle. From the low level street soldiers peddling drugs to fiends all the way up to those reaping all the spoils of the war on drugs.  From the nameless beat cop, to the insignia flashing Majors, and money shuffling senators. Throughout all that we find ourselves rooting for 'good' people who do despicable things, and 'bad' people who are trying to do the right thing.
We stumble across addicts trying to change their lives around only to shoot up again the next day. We meet cops trying not to make a fuss about the decay of the justice system so they don't jeopardize their chances at a promotion. Some hard working detectives who want to find the truth against mounting pressure from superiors who are afraid their skeletons might be revealed. Gangsters with a conscience, and monsters with no remorse. By the end of the season you begin to doubt yourself when you think about who's who. The boys in blue terrorize the neighborhood with almost as much gusto as those drug dealers protecting their territory.
Is it the classic a "few bad apples ruins the bunch" mentality that breeds this problem? Or is it more complex? Is the whole system corrupt to the core? We see good people do things we'd be against, but it's all for the "greater good" so we let it slide, but what else will we let slide when the stakes are raised higher?
We see honorable men and women lie cheat and steal, but we soon learn nothing is black and white. And yet out in those baltimore streets that seems to be all you can find.

"The Wire" has been described as the best TV drama ever, and other comparable superlatives.  For years I avoided watching it, because, given its subject matter, I thought it would be depressing.  (I'm a former public defender; these are my clients; their stories are depressing.)  Well, it IS just about the best TV drama I've ever seen.  It is saved from being depressing, for me anyway, by (1) the generally excellent performances, and (2) the brisk storytelling--there's too much going on for you to become depressed over the story.  If you care about good storytelling you won't be disappointed. (Image is from Season 4 premier.)
An excellent drama that shines a light on the harshness of city life and the politics of policing.

A gritty drugs and cops drama that is sophisticated adult entertainment.  The acting is excellent and the characters exceptionally complex.  My only complaint is that the police corruption and incompetence is so blatant as to be unbelievable.  Cops beating witnesses in interrogation rooms is routine, many cops are alcoholic derelicts, and several high-level officers are "on the take."  If that's even close to the truth about Baltimore, the Feds or State-level forces need to take over the city police, like they did in 1930s Kansas City.  Judging from recent events in Baltimore, it appears to be accurate, so I plan to avoid the city.

There are many reviews of The Wire so I am not going to say anything about the cinematography, the directing, or the cast. Instead, I am going to be philosophical about it and pronounce that The Wire is the reality show that gives me a glance into a world that is too frightening for me to venture in at any capacity in real life. Everyone should watch The Wire for entertainment but I hope everyone who watches it thinks about how wonderful it would be if all parties represented in the show would put aside self-preservation, self-interests and territories, and really concentrate on helping each other overcome ignorance, greed, racism, apathy, and heartlessness.

What a fabulous show. Excellent acting, sets, cinematography, scripts, etc. It details how law enforcement works inside corrupt government and how a right-fighting person, like the lead detective, get regularly mistreated. There is a lot of humor mixed into reality. Season one is set in the urban street drug market in Baltimore. Season two focuses on dock corruption and the unions in Baltimore. The viewer travels with the same main police figures and citizens as others are added and eliminated. By the end of the series, everything not previously explained is explained. We felt like we lost our family when the series ended. Moral to the story: Justice is a rarely seen commodity in life and in this series, but then there's Omar. He who lives by the sword...

Still the greatest show of all time (even better now that it is in HD).  With the advent of the riots in Baltimore, this show has only become more relevant and timely.  I really can't say enough about this show, it truly deserves a 100% rating.  10/10 on imdb.  The show is definitely NOT for everyone but you can't possibly please everyone when making a TV show... or Movie... or song.  No matter what media you chose as your form of expression, there will always be someone who hates it.  Haters gonna hate.

This show is a true story of life on the crime riddled streets of Baltimore.  It was written by people who saw it first hand.  And are still seeing it today.

This show requires a class titled "An Introduction to The Wire" because it comes right out of the gate shooting and doesn't let up.  Every character is in the first episode.  And they throw the viewer right into the legal process that is our justice system, the Baltimore Police Department and the "kids" living on the streets of Baltimore.  Probably one of the most defining characteristics of this show (compared to most Cop Dramas) is how you see BOTH perspectives, Cops AND criminals. You see life from the perspective of the "kids" on the street... and I am using quotes when I say kids for many reasons.  A good friend of mine stopped watching the show in Season 4 because it became too emotional heavy for her. This show is HEAVY.

The Wire is complex.  If you give it a few episodes and actually pay attention, you will not be disappointed.  Another tip if you are struggling with this show... turn on the subtitles.  The true language of the streets, cops and whoever is not always easy to understand... even hardcore English linguists will be blown away.

Not only will you see life on the streets in Baltimore from the perspective of the cops and the kids on the streets... you will also get a view into the complex lives of the drug addicts, lawyers, politicians, school teachers, dock workers and Judges.  Every character on the show is just trying to survive the complex institutions they have become a part of... the BPD, drug dealers, our legal system... family was the most complex and heart breaking system on this show.

So go ahead and compare this show to other cop dramas but IMO it does not compare at all.  The Wire aired from 2002-2008 (A year after I moved to Baltimore).  The Wire will entertain, educate (hopefully not confuse) and cry TODAY and for years to come.  Wait... what is a BEEPER? The only TV show that can compare to The Wire in quality, social message, complexity and re-watch-ability is the Twilight Zone.

I normally don't write reviews but a recent review state that this was a terrible series and I must disagree strongly with that assessment. The wire is one of the best if not the best tv series to hit the screens. It is close to real life as Ive ever seen especially growing up in a similar setting. I can understand not liking it but to say it is distasteful and such doesnt do it justice. The individual that wrote that terrible review either lives in a shoebox or not in the real world.

After about ten minutes of non-stop, foul-mouthing by what I assume are the "good guys" in this series, I knew it was not something that would entertain or enliven, inspire or uplift, so that was the first-and-last episode of THE WIRE for me.  There is more than enough of the crude, profane, obscene, and disgusting in the news and the world at large.. Why anyone would choose to spend precious personal time immersing him or herself in such unapologetic, unrelenting squalor of mind and spirit is beyond me. If THE WIRE is "true to life," then it represents a reality about which I do not wish to know more.  As one who loves the English language, I find the dialogue in this program to be in a language almost wholly foreign to me and my experience over a long lifetime - a language with no redeeming social, intellectual,  spiritual, or artistic value. Those who speak this foreign tongue are so alien to my world and do such violence to decent, civil, human expression that I find any further voluntary submission to such unpleasant verbal assaults unthinkable.  I have no idea what the plot(s) might have been but was unwilling to spend one moment more with the thoroughly distasteful characters who introduced the story lines. They made me want to seek other company - FAST - so I did.  . .

Finally, we're able to stream movies and videos, and thanks to Amazon Prime we are almost through the first season of what has to have been one of the truly great TV shows on cable. We look forward to four more seasons of "The Wire".

I enjoyed the 1st season of The Wire.  The characters were a little slow to develop, and at times I felt like I needed a translator, but I found myself immediately watching the next episode because I had to know what happened next.  I watched the last 6 episodes in one sitting.

I saw "The Wire" during  its original run on HBO. Now, I'm watching it all over again (for free), with my Amazon Fire TV and Amazon Prime.

I look at it this way-there are three types of TV programming: network, cable, and pay. The best network show was "Law & Order." For cable, it was "Breaking Bad." For pay TV, it's "The Wire." Since all three have ended their runs, and have had time to compare and contrast, I would rate The Wire the best TV show ever, just by a nose over Breaking Bad. Just one man's opinion!
