Listen, ladies and gents, this show is a masterpiece. Well worth it to watch all five seasons. You will immerse yourself in a community/culture at a level that transcends most television. That being said, both seasons one and two take a little orientation and focus to get into. This is because the show introduces so many characters at first, and takes the proper time to let the viewer acclimate to their respective stories. That's the only reason that season one and two got four stars instead of five. Otherwise, this show is perfect. That is, if you like a story-driven drama. This show is like real life. Lots of ups and down. Lots of losses and not much victory. Justice doesn't always happen. Characters make heart-wrenching decisions in heart-wrenching circumstances. Sometimes it is very anti-climactic, just like life. So, if you are looking for fast-paced action with explosions, keep looking. If you are looking to connect emotionally with a story and have your views changed on certain aspects of life, then this is a must watch.

One of the greatest TV police series ever.  Dedicated Baltimore police officers survive and do their best to fight the unwinnable war on drugs against the police hierarchy and the drug gangs of Baltimore.  They swim against the tide.  So well acted.  As good as Homicide:Life on the Streets.

The Wire is not just great television; it is important television.

Many comparisons are made to the excellence of this series. However, I cannot think of a single drama--outside of this one--that rewards the viewer, repeatedly, each time one goes back for a re-watch.

If The Wire had not been so ahead of its time--in forcing adult themes upon the perpetually adolescent American public--and been an AMC series, I can imagine fifteen to twenty characters who I, and I presume the public, would love to get to know via an origin story series.

Who would not like to know more about:

- What young Daniels was up to that got him in so much hot water with Chief of Police.
- Bunk and McNulty's early years.
- The previous generation of Barksdales.
- The rise of Prop Joe.
- Marlo Stanfield's early years and struggles.
- Who ran docks when the Sabotkas were young.
- Where the Greek came from?
- Brother Muzzone's career, and the story of his regular employer in NY.
- Omar's early years.
- Levy's "other" clients.
- The rise of Clay Davis.
- Where Snoop came from? I mean, we know "where" she came from, but her story would be fascinating.
- Young Gus chasing stories down.

And so many more. David Simon gave us such rich, interesting characters, they populate our imagination even when they are not a part of a scene or storyline.

I am so thankful for this series' evenhanded peek behind the curtains of a single city, as it let me know what television could have been (if we had a more discerning public).

This is a must watch for anyone, young or old.

One more thing: How is Netflix going through great pains to bring back Full House and Arrested Development, giving untold millions to Adam Sandler to produce content "at a future date," and giving so many millions to any comic that will do 45 minutes of stand-up in a dark room, but have not put together a team to bring any of these Wire series ideas to fruition?

Everything has a number, even David Simon. Full creative control and a House of Cards-like budget should be enough to close the deal.

Let's make this happen!

Despite being a little dated - most of this season revolves around pagers. I remember those but how many other watchers do. Anyway, a really good procedural cop show set in gritty Baltimore. A great ensemble cast, both cops and dealers. Throw in an occasional role reversal (cops as scumbags and honorable dealers) and this series has it all. Detective McNulty (the lead) is a complicated man, not without his (glaring) faults. The episodes are wonderfully written with realistic (for the '90's) dialog. Direction is fast paced and sometimes really innovative. Give this a watch. You'll binge too (I'm already half way through the second season).

This is season 1, which set up the best series ever on Television.  I am a serial-binge TV watcher and this show, this season are addicting from the opening theme to the credits rolling at the end of each episode. The two guys who wrote the show, Ed Burns, a retired Baltimore Police Detective and David Simon, who works for the B-More Sun Times wove an intricate tale that all started in the first season.

The show featured some local Baltimore talent and was filmed entirely on location in B-more.  The actors were all really good.  One of the actors, who played a Baltimore Police Homicide Sgt. is in real life a Baltimore Police Detective Sgt. working in a homicide unit.  So many pieces of this intricately woven tale were set up in season 1.  From opening to closing, it is the best tale told on TV.

For cop show fans, The Wire is a must see. More than a procedural, more than a defective detective chronicle, more than a sum of crime drama stereotypes, The Wire's gritty realism captures a segment of American society in a way that is both thought provoking and entertaining. Explicit sexual content, (a characteristic of HBO "adult" dramas), is kept to a minimum. Explicit violence is not, but never comes across as unwarranted or exploitative. Traditional boundaries defining hero and villain are blurred in an engaging storyline that is expertly rendered on all levels. The Wire sets a standard for American police/crime drama that is rarely, if ever, achieved in the entertainment industry. All that said, it needs to be noted that the depiction of the use of firearms by law enforcement does not reflect current (2014-2015) revelations on police behavior seen in the media.

The Wire is not for children and I would personally exercise caution recommending it to young teens.

First, to be clear, this series is excellent. All 5 seasons. I commend it to you, with suitable cautions for profanity, violence, and some mildly explicit sex. My attraction to The Wire may be a bit idiosyncratic, so it seems fair to expose its basis for the reader to judge.

It is not a crime mystery. The bad guys are apparent and in a sense eternal. It is not a morality play. The righteous do not prevail. They win some and lose some and by the end it's tough to tell the score, and even hard to identify the righteous. It is not an action/adventure, though there is plenty of action and adventure to keep our attention.

Instead, the series is a portrait of the American city at the beginning of the 21st century with Baltimore as the paradigm. It uses the struggle to establish the rule of law as the principle dramatic vehicle. Each season the crime/enforcement theme is supplemented by sub-themes from other aspects of the urban institutional environment, the industrial economy, the political system, the educational system, the press, the other traditional pillars supporting the city. The failure of the city is intimately tied to the failure of each of these pillars, and the series makes it clear that this nexus of failure occurred within the memory of the older adults who populate the tale, those old enough to have seen their children reach adulthood.

The compelling power of The Wire is it portrayal of the human scale consequences of the failure of the city, the consequences on individual lives and the microcosms of urban life, the corner, the stoop, the office, the shop, the classroom, the courtroom, the bar, the home, the family. The impact isn't static and passive, it is dynamic and adaptive and smart. When the system doesn't work, when it has failed catastrophically, those caught in the mess carve out new rules, make new institutions, find new solutions. They aren't stupid. They're creative and energetic and hard working and ambitious. But they're also not wise. The solutions they create to short term immediate problems make things worse in the long term.

The great mystery is how all these different mutually supporting systems could have failed at once, with such catastrophic consequences. The series offers a number of candidates. Corruption is offered as partial explanation, but not simply the petty corruption of money and greed, though certainly it plays a role. There is also the corruption of ambition for power and status, and the corruption of evasion and cowardice. But perhaps the most insidious corruption of all is the corruption of righteousness, the reckless oblivion induced by the belief that a noble goal justifies ignoble means.

Drugs are clearly presented as another source of decay. An experiment in controlling drug related crime that actually works (in fiction at least) is quashed after a brief flirtation because it offends the ideals of the community. It is hard to know what conclusions to draw from this but in the real world I watch Colorado and Washington state with interest.

Measurement is an odd villain of the piece. Statistics and testing, we are told, are obstacles to law enforcement and education. I found this to be sadly superficial. Certainly managing the numbers rather than managing the processes is foolish and corrupt, but that is a failure of bad management, lazy and superficial supervision, rather than a consequence of measurement. Feelings and Caring and Commitment are weak substitutes.

In the end the urban mandala has spun through a cycle, archetypes are reincarnated, innovations are banished, and the beat goes on. All that changes is that the viewer has had a chance to gain a better understanding of the state of things. We are not offered any glimmer of hope that the dynamics of the urban environment can improve.

This is my second time watching this fine series. In many ways, it is modern Shakespeare; at times lyrical, hilarious and ultimately, tragic. We are made to care about each of the characters in the fine and delicate writing, from the speculation about the McNuggets' creator, to McNulty's working the case to the calamitous end. The victory seems hollow, as a police is down and the one boy, Wallace, who wanted nothing more to do with any of it, is dead. Dee, who takes the fall for Stringer and Avon is horrified when he finds out from the police interview that Wallace is one of the bodies that just pile up over the drugs; the one he knew for a fact would never snitch takes the 20 and begins to read and learn in prison. But, he isn't safe there; there are hot-shots, a network that reach from the high-rises into the penitentiary. All Dee really wants is what Wallace wanted. A place to breathe free. It is a telling want: the chance to really be a free man, without worrying about the consequences of a wrong action, either a demotion or a bullet. To say nothing of the competition. To make the whole thing just a bit eerie, we have Omar, who robs drug dealers and his telling whistle "the cheese stands alone" almost puts us on "Nightmare in Elm Street" territory. Not a line or a scene or a situation is wasted in the first season of "The Wire". It is simply the finest show I have ever witnessed; I'm sure when I watch it again, I'll pick up more.

The Wire is hands down the best crime series ever written for television.  Its characters are diverse and interesting.  The story is starkly realistic and character-driven.  Omar Little, a homosexual drug robber who is motivated by street morals and the desire to avenge a slain lover and confederate, is one of the best characters ever written for TV.  Senator Clay Davis is phenomenal.  The characters of Detective Jimmy McNulty, Detective Lestor Freamon, Detective Kema Greggs, and Detective Bunk Moreland are each wonderfully complete and idiosyncratic in their own way.  Lt. Cedric Daniels sets the archetypal mold for best unit commander on a crime show, in my opinion.  The list of great characters goes on and on. The criminals are just as fascinating as the cops, politicians, teachers, union bosses, and newspaper men.  I can't think of another show that provided a more diverse array of roles for African-American actors.

The Wire involves an intricate web of characters and subplots that stretch across its several seasons.  That intricacy is perhaps why the series was not recognized for its greatness when it first aired on HBO in the early 2000s.  But it is, in fact, a great show, albeit one that the viewer has to invest time in to understand and follow.  I heartily recommend it.

The reason I decided to give it a shot is because I was listening to the wrap up show on Stern. They said something along the lines of it being the most important cop drama show you'll ever watch. They were right. I've never felt like I understood the politics and intricacies of how things worked through all the other BS crime dramas that are on TV. They make it seem too easy, and it probably is. This, I feel, is the most accurate portrayal of what's going on in the police officers world when dealing with this situation. I'm towards the end of the first season and I'm hooked. If you're a crime drama person and you're on the fence about this, I highly recommend it.

The episodes that preceded "The Game" actually condensed the primary characters into human beings that can be recognized in our world order. Mainly, The Game serves as a metaphor for why so many people today seemingly lack trust in politics and associated good citizens who seemingly control that public trust.
Moreover, it also helps to realize that drama based upon fact can be reminder of what our society needs to address.

Count me among those who find The Wire to be the greatest television show ever, and by "greatest," I mean having the most serious intent, commitment to authenticity, and intellectual content. What seems to be a police procedural (and it only seems to be one: the viewer discovers that it is not by the second season, and its full scope--the city of Baltimore from street corner drug pushers and addicts to those who inhabit its corridors of power--only becomes evident by the third season) is about ideas, specifically the many ways in which our nation has gone dreadfully wrong, and its corruption and decadence, not in any lurid or moralizing sense, but in the strict sense of failure to live up to its purported ideals and a paralyzing weakness that results in an inability to change. But it is not a documentary, or even a didactic drama: no single character articulates this theme, nor is this a culminating catharsis foisted upon the viewer. Instead, it is the conclusion one reaches after accumulating a mountain of small details, just as the drug case that is the narrative backbone of the first season is made not from any one piece of evidence, but a great curated collection of actions, transactions, and conversations.
This stance that "all the pieces matter" means that criminal enterprises--to name but one organization the series places under scrutiny--in The Wire are the result of small, coordinated acts by numerous people, and so many expectations viewers have of a police procedural will be frustrated: there are no gun battles, or car chases, or dramatic confrontations between cops and criminals. In fact, The Wire seems to delight in frustrating and ridiculing these expectations: the first time a cop fires his gun in the series is by accident, and then while in the office, and tactical teams lining up to smash down doors are told to stand down and calm down by detectives who know their quarry, and that the weapons of choice for these criminals are not guns, but skilled defense attorneys.
The DVD sets of The Wire, unfortunately, are only adequate. The transfer is good, but not great, and there's a paucity of extra features in a series that calls out for them. Unfortunately, if a viewer wants to see The Wire as its creators--David Simon, Ed Burns, Robert Colesbury--intended, these are the discs to get, for the upcoming Blu-Ray HD widescreen version is not a restoration: The Wire was filmed and edited for 4:3 aspect ratio and standard definition playback.

The Wire is a great depiction of the seedy side of Baltimore Maryland. A rare glimpse into how the drug trade works in the inner city. As you watch you can't help but think, this is how it all goes down. You probably think that, because IT IS. This may not be accurate to a T on how all drug cartels do business but it could be. The actors in The Wire have all gone on to do great things, or are already established in Hollywood. The acting is where The Wire shines. Hell, even some of the baddies are loveable. Sometimes you will find yourself rooting for the Omar, the neighborhood Robin Hood who robs drugs from the dealers and gives them to the poor. Did I mention Omar is a homosexual who walks around the projects with a shotgun? He's just one character who makes this series extremely satisfying and interesting. Give The Wire a try and watch Season 1 and pretty soon you'll find that you can't just watch one episode.

Suspenseful, gut-wrenching and discouraging portrait of inner city life. But always entertaining. The characters are well-rounded and realistic - no heroes and villains, just frail humans trying to make their way in a flawed society.
One of the greatest shows ever created.

If you can get past the profanity, this is very entertaining.  Showing the insider politics of the police bureaucracy,  you see just how difficult fighting crime really is.  The characters are very believable, self-centered and ruthless, just like real life.  There is very little dullness, and as you learn and begin to understand the characters,  you can at least see the viewpoint of corrupt or deadbeat cops, scumbag drug dealers and human traffickers. The story follows multiple characters along their conflicted lives tied together by a crime ring, either fighting it or supporting it.  If you ever wondered what goes on in the inner city projects, this is a gritty look at harsh reality.

Crime drama set in Bmore, possibly best series ever made.  Very real, without excessive violence and sex (okay, depends in what you call excessive).  The characters are going to stay with you for years.  The dialogue, plots, and sub-plots are  just excellent.  Each season uses a different theme, but generally follows the same police characters as they navigate their jobs and lives.  The "bad guys" are intricate and well-developed, gaining your respect for even armed robbers, murderers and kingpins.  Each season has a well-developed, synchronized plot that is nicely completed within that season.

I watched this years ago, but just started a rewatch. It's amazing how well this show holds up over the years. It doesn't seem at all campy like some shows do the second time through. It's still just as gritty and real.

You also notice how well thought out the whole story was prior to filming when you watch the second time through. Since you know what happens in the end, and how things play out along the way, you can see a lot of care went into making sure there was continuity throughout the show.

If anything, I like it more the second time.

One of the biggest complaints about The Wire presented in an HD format is that the original look and feel of the show is lost due to image cropping at the top and bottom of the screen to make the originally square image fit on a widescreen TV.

I'm a stickler for that sort of thing. And I watched The Wire on HBO when it came out in it's original format. And I didn't even notice the difference. The show transforms to a 16:9 ratio very well without impacting the artistic quality of the series.

So don't hesitate to watch The Wire presented on Amazon in a widescreen format. The quality is great and you'll enjoy the show just as much (or more) than you did the first time you watched it.

One of the best shows for television ever. A totally different cops and bad guys series, The Wire delves into the politics of both the police and the dope peddlers, and finds each of them pretty dark and ugly. It's not an action show like all the other cop shows, though there is plenty of action in The Wire. The writers and creator of the show put far more attention to the dialog and plot of the show. What comes from the mouths of actors rings true even if I've never been to Baltimore nor with the police or heroin pushers.

Each episode is not independent: season 1 is really one extended show over 13 episodes. It gives the watcher time to learn the personalities of the characters. And there are some incredible characters here: McNulty (or McNutty, according to confidential informant Bubbles) is the lead character of the show (though it is the show itself that is the "star") but he is on the screen barely half the time. The criminals (Omar, Stringer, Dee and the boys) are as interesting and multi-dimentional as the "good guys". And, "good" and "bad" are sometimes hard to distinguish, which is much closer to real life than anything you will see on the rest of TV.

The Wire is the best, or at least one of the few great, shows on television, now or in the past.

"Whether one is a cop, a longshoreman, a drug dealer, a politician, a judge or a lawyer, all are ultimately compromised and must contend with whatever institution to which they are committed." - David Simon, creator of "The Wire"

"The Wire" is a bitter pill to swallow for a lot of people.

The atmosphere is bleak and dreary from the drug infested projects to the dusty basement Daniels' team is given to set up shop.  There are no flawless heroes in the police department and even many of the criminals have shades of grey. The ensemble cast is huge (and hugely talented) requiring the viewers to pay close attention to the interwoven narratives and not play with their smartphones while watching.

This is not a show for people who think all cops are trustworthy and competent, all criminals are greedy and evil, and that the War On Drugs is actually working. It's for people who have the stomach to watch a display of poverty, corruption, red tape, violence, addiction, and long hours of police work subverted more often by careerists in the department than by the criminals they investigate.

The only flaw that left me unsatisfied concerned the fate of children in the care of a character who dies; there is no mention of what happened to them.  Then again, that might be the point: not every loose end is tied off when a case is closed.  As Omar Little says "It's all in the game!"

If you like it dark and gritty but intelligent, challenging, and moving, then this show is for you.

To what extent is this show faithful to the real world? Movie and TV cop shows are overwhelmingly risible PR jobs intended to show cops as capable defenders of citizens assaulted by crimininals. The characters are allowed to trip up sometimes, but in the end they are portrayed as noble mostly men. It's tragic that real life is showing up, daily, the obscenity of (un)reality shows such as "Cops", that are allowed to continue. (But I digress.)

It is tragically refreshing to see, for a change, a policing organization full of corrupt, crude, uncouth, stupid and fed up policemen, up and down the ranks, who depend on the tax-paying Citizens' generosity for ther jobs, salaries and pensions. And who don't give a rat's posterior about those Citizens, as they defer to their powerful and wealthy patrons who view the cops as their useful idiots who, gradually, in the course of their policing duties, become just like their targets: brutal, unsparing and vindictive primitives, often destroying the hard work of those who take their jobs seriously. So for that, 5 stars is not enough.

On the other hand I have other concerns:
- the acting is so-so, with some notable exceptions. It's not bad enough to quit watching the show; it does manage to compel one to return at a reluctant frequency. (Disclosure: I'm still in Season 1, and hoping that as the crew comes together in the following Seasons, so will their work.)
- the story unfolds at a pace that is at times too slooooooooow.
- the script is too wordy. Kind of like the early movies at the time they turned "talkies". Scripts are supposed to take cues from real conversations, not take down everything verbatim. Add to that...
- the terrible diction. Consider: for the massive majority of viewers the inside language of the Black getto dwellers is a foreign language. Most words and expressions, however, are not too difficult to guess. However(#2), the sloppy diction makes half of the dialogues, at least for this reviewer, unintelligible. That's just too bad. Just for fun I had once rewound one portion several times to try and grasp the exchange word for word. The unexpurgated language doesn't bother me, but I find the insider language much more interesting, informative, revealing and entertaining. If only American actors learned to fake speaking with a semi-opened mouth, but at the same time made themselves understood. Kind of like the British actors most of whom attend real acting schools, like RADA. Bad diction is not only unprofessional, but is does a disservice to the actors uttering those words and undercuts the effort of the writers who, very possibly, like most scribblers, agonize over ever word. Thus the actors are flattening the story, while cutting off a dimension of the character they are playing.
- as a recent victim of police stupidity and brutality, I have noticed that the police are not unlike the criminals they pursue. Only the police can kill, harrass and offend with the blessing of the authorities. (vide the Fergusson, and so many other, cases). This is something that the writers show with an honesty that should inspire our insipid lawmakers to make changes before the US police become the SS of our times. (Yes, that is how the NAZI stormtroopers learned their craft.)
- finally, the production values, from direction, photography, costumes, etc., are good, considering the insane pace that plagues made-for-TV shows.

All in all, the show is a good document for posterity: the USA in the early 21st century.

Why should I care about any of these characters?  Crooked, big-city cops.  Corrupt or incompetent from the top down.  Scum bag drug dealers make a killing feeding the addictions of low-life project junkies.  This is the plot of a hundred serial dramas of the past.  This one however, compels you to pay attention to details and nuances.  The victories are short-lived, incomplete and only open up a new box of problems.  The defeats just present more opportunities.  "That's how the game is played."

I  was born, raised, lived and worked in the inner city of Cleveland. This story occurs in the projects of Baltimore. If you don't understand the language of the ghetto, don't watch this show. It's a hard hitting, gutsy portrayal of what's going on in our urban areas today and what's been happening for the last sixty years in the black community due to democratic paternalism. A task force of incompetent cops is formed and transformed into a cohesive team utilizing their individual strengths. Throughout season 1, a subplot emerges that demonstrates why and how people like Barak H Obama and Eric Holder move up the ladder in corrupt illegitimate positions of power. Absolute power corrupts absolutely.

I was looking forward to beginning "The Wire", but my husband and I could not even make it through the first episode.  Almost every sentence, even those uttered by persons supposedly in positions of authority and respect,  had the word "f***" in it, for no reason whatsoever.  I do not believe that even the grittiest police officers toss out the epithet all the time, in all situations, in front of the public, each other, judges....even the judges were using it.  When writers demonstrate a total lack of creativity (see: the ability to write without having to fall back on swearing), I am not going to waste the time to watch.  Grow up, folks, and learn how to use the language to tell the story.

Some productions are worth watching strictly for their entertainment value. This series is not one of them. There is nothing entertaining about being exposed to depravity, to sociopaths, to incompetence- both individual and bureaucratic- to characters that are often prone to make stupid decisions, and those that display inappropriate behavior. However, it is very useful, now and then, to be reminded that such "imperfections" exist in our society, in our social organizations (especially in governmental bureaucracies). This series' primary value-add is to serve as such a reminder, and is worth being exposed to for that reason.

I'm late to the party on this one, but recently discovered this show and am currently binge watching (currently 26 episodes in, in under a week) it's that good.  Well written, and well acted; and it's great to see do many of my favorite actors from other shows all together in this.  There's a lot going on in each episode and a lot of characters to keep up with but it's nicely paced and never dull, you must pay attention though because details will come back from previous episodes, previous seasons even.  It's not something that can be jumped into in the middle it's a continuous story arc to be followed.  Kind of happy I wasn't watching from original air date, by being able to watch in a short time frame I have less time to forget details between episodes.  Fantastic crime/cop show

HBO shows have come a really long way in the past 10 years. The acting in the Wire falls well short of your Game of Thrones, Sopranos, Boardwalk Empire brands we are used to.  However the cast is strong as all the main and secondary actors have made pretty good careers and are pretty familiar faces. The story is good and keeps you watching because the entire season is one story and one case. Some young people might find it very hard to watch as no one these days knows what a pay phone or a pager is and it is from a time before computers were in an inner-city police department. But this is a great throwback for anyone born before 1985 and can appreciate how things were done the hard way because it was the only way back then.

If realism is the intention, then are the cops really as bad as the dealers. Is the attention realism or a more sinister political motive. And does this summary mean irony, coincidence or parody? Is the point drawn out for puzzlement, for distraction, or something else? Is it really a moral statement or political one? And is irony the red herring or not? Is the meaning deep, or deep as a cover for shallow? Is shocking reality, or a shocking distraction? Is everything as it seems? Is it all the straight up truth or irony, is parody there, is intentionally the intention? Is it a cover for a cover up, if so which situation is it really?

The Wire is a masterpiece of writing, acting, filming, and editing.  This dramatic series explores the entanglements of poverty, drugs, crime and political corruption abetted by bureaucratic turf-building, greed and political corruption in a large American city, Baltimore, and can be extrapolated to any other urban area.

Don't watch this if you want an emotional massage to make you feel good.  It's a powerful, realistic portrayal of life and drugs in the ghetto and the slime that exploits and profits from drug money.

Baltimore homicide detective Jimmy McNulty gets into hot water and is assigned to a detail of outcasts tasked with investigating drug lord Avon Barksdale and his operation. The plot involves numerous individuals and twists and turns - too many, after awhile. While well written, the degree of incompetence/malevolence at the top becomes unbelievable after awhile, and the length of the series is far too long for my taste.

The really good news - no ads.
Multilayered and slow to peel but worth every delicious turn. Me love, my husband no love.

Raw, gritty, unpredictable, multi layered stories.

Edgy, gritty, funny, absurd ... By turns, The Wire takes you through evolving city tales of drugs, justice, corruption, betrayal and just about every other means of human interaction.  Some find the story evolves slowly - but stick with you.  You will be very glad you did.

A friend of ours called it a "slow burn," which turned out to be accurate.  However, by the second half of season 1, and pretty much all the way through season 4, we were completely addicted.  If you end up watching the whole series, season 1 is almost better the second time around - you pick up on things that were hard to catch the first time when names were flying around like a disturbed hornet's nest.  Not to say I felt cheated or like I was missing anything the first time, but going back a second time ends up shedding new light.
Season 1 is great, season 2 is too, but season 3 is amazing.  Season 4 is also amazing - maybe even my favorite - but it is also really tough, perhaps the most difficult in terms of emotional strife.

This show has been called the greatest television series of all time and there is a reason.  This is not your typical cop drama.  It isn't your typical mob show.  It isn't your typical show about politics or blue collar people.  It is a study in sociology.  It is an examination of a large eastern port city rife with drug crime and murder.  The characters are based upon real people and some of those real people actually show up in the series.  This series is more reality television than any housewives, bachelor, fake castaways, or 20 somethings living in an apartment acting like buffoons could ever portray.  Sure, the show is dated by today's standards.  The lack of social media and world view of just after 9/11 shows but much of what you see is relevant today.  The game is the game and that was as true for me 20 years ago as it is today.  Ignore the 1 or 2 star or 3 star votes.  They didn't watch the show or they didn't relate to any portion.  They couldn't get past the grit.  One person complained about the swearing.  Newsflash, people swear... especially the people portrayed in this series.  Check this out for yourself.  Its an amazing expose on inner city life.

This was the best series ever produced by HBO so far.  I loved The Sorprano's and am enjoying Game of Thrones but THE WIRE is the best of the lot.  You hate the good guys sometimes and love the bad ones but no matter what you have an emotional response to everyone in the cast.  It is not just a cop show it deals with politcs race relations greed.  It a a whose who of the seven deadly sins aand why they are deadly.  Spend a winter weekend with the wire and a glass of wine you will never regret it.

Other reviewers have pretty much exhausted the superlatives that can be used about this deliberately paced, very intelligent, wholly character-driven show.  To be brief then, I just watched the first season and I am hooked.  The slower pace makes the viewer pay attention as each character is developed, whether drug dealer or cop, and is revealed as a 3-dimensional person containing some good and some bad.  The Projects, where much of this takes place, can also be seen, in its way, as a complex character of its own.  Excellent entertainment, well worth watching.

There are those who would give Jesus 1 Star.  Such is the world we live in.  A few people said the acting was bad.  I say it's some of the best acting ever.  Some people are offended by the profanity used by the charters who sell drugs and murder for a living.  Duh...  Well no  " Ned Flanders " here on this show buba-reno.  IMHO this show is nothing short of a modern master piece  There are five seasons.  to get the full impact of the show you must see all five seasons.  Also, and I do not mean to offend anyone; white people are not really the stars of this show.  This can subconsciously skew some peoples perceptions.
Often in movie or TV  discussions with co-workers I find that while I have seen the shows that have little to no blacks in them, my white counterparts rarely can say the same for any show where blacks are in the lead. This is not a put down, just and observation.

 So for those who think Breaking Bad ( Love it great show) is the best show ever; this may not be your cup of tea.  Someone mentioned that they were not " entertained"  I can understand that.  Depending on your empathy level the show can be somewhat brutal at  times.  Ok hears the deal.  If you are of average intelligence and have an open mind; and watch ALL 5 Season , when  the final curtain drops you will say " I understand"

You will walk away with understanding that is both profound and disturbing.
This is  the : BEST SHOW IN THE HISTORY OF TV,  BAR none .  Compared to what you say?  The Shield , SOA, Dexter, and yes Breaking Bad.

Side note:  Word was at one time,  that Quentin Tarantino  was going to do a movie based on the Omar character.

Season one tells a heart wrenching story in depth and detail about the impact street drugs have on society including but not limited to the addicts, the providers, the police and government officials. I have always preferred books for their depth of the story characters,  but this was incredible as I could see the streets and not just read about it. There is some violence and pornography but focus is on why it is happening. Each episode left me craving for the next. It is a heart wrenching and provides the opportunity to witness the characters daily life, their struggles and why bad choices are made by many due to the control and greed of a few.
 It is well worth watching again.

No disrespect to Mr. Gandolfini or Ms Falco.  Is there a miscast actor in the WIRE?  Is there a story line than makes no sense?

Up until watching The Wire, my favorite police oriented drama had been NYPD Blue, in spite of how loaded it was with anti self defense propaganda.  But The Wire blows any other police drama I've seen out the door.  Ever wonder why Baltimore, with highly restrictive gun laws, could have a murder rate even higher than Chicago, and 6 times the rate in NYC?  Well, The Wire, although fictional, offers some choice examples of how corrupt politicians and their police can allow such situations to thrive.

Yes, it's difficult for some to take the constant "f" and "n" bombs, but they fit with the overall dramatic content of the show.  After all, the subject is how a police task force goes about getting information to arrest members of a criminal gang selling drugs, and enforcing their will be murder.
Two events stand out spectacularly.  In the first, the main character and his partner go over an old murder scene, and, using their knowledge of how crimes are committed, gradually figure out how the murder occurred.  And they do this without the nonsensical Sherlock Holmes "brilliant deduction" nonsense so prevalent in the typical TV and movie dramas supposedly about police activities.  The second event spans the end of one of the latter episodes in the season and the beginning of the next.  I won't give it away, but these are two of THE most gut wrenching TV scenes I've ever seen in my 60+ years.  Again, unlike the other TV series nonsense, the scenes are believable.
These are just two standout events from a series which towers above every other TV cop show, in scene after scene.  If you like police dramas and can get around the language, see this series.  But I have to warn you, there was a downside for me.  After beginning this series, I have little patience for the usual drivel shown on other TV cop shows.
This is a the most realistic police drama I've ever scene

I live in Baltimore and for years have heard people talk about The Wire.  Never had HBO or whatever channel it was aired on, but happily recently realized we have access to it for free through Amazon Prime.  As soon as I knew that, I started watching, and then had to binge watch because I was hooked.  It's a little bit dated - as in, I think it was filmed in 2002?  So they use beepers and pay phones.  But I quickly got past that, and found it to be a really excellent drama.  It gripped me and was everything I had heard.  My only criticism is that, obviously, it paints a very bleak picture of Baltimore.  Sadly, it is all TRUE...it just doesn't let an uninformed viewer know that there are equally wonderful and attractive things about the city, and that people other than drug dealers and dirtballs do live here!  It's a view of the seamy underbelly that is painful but like any disaster, you can't take your eyes away.

This is an awesome TV series about the very sad truth about the current urban environment, in a declining economically depressed city. An extremely accurate look at what happens to the inner city and it's people when drugs, corruption, and greed rule the land.

Why is this HBO hit so accurate?  Easy to figure out, the two creators (and earlier episode writers) lived in this world. One was a homicide detective with the BCPD. Who better to write about very real inter-working of drug crimes, gang control of the lives of the people trapped in this world, and the brutal and senseless murders and beatings that go with that territory.

The second creator/writer was a newspaper reporter for the Baltimore Sun. And much to his credit and everlasting value to the community, he was fired by the paper when his stories got a little to close to the truth of the rampant corruption, of all kickbacks, and payoffs to contractors , politicians, and dirty police on the take......  All on the take, .... all part of the problem.  So, instead....  he created a brilliant HBO series to tell the truth, (and make some mega bucks doing it I'm sure)

 .... God bless them both, they give us a very realistic insight into a world that most average Americans never will see or, be exposed to, but maybe we should all be exposed for us see:  This depicts the very real desolation of our inter-cities and what the rampant, the absolute decline of morals and values do to the human beings caught up in the misery,.

This is sometimes not easy to watch, the violence, the stark moral decline of American culture, the hopeless, pathetic fate of those trapped in this insane maze with seemingly no way out is tough to take. But the real world really is sometimes hard to face and after we can face it, maybe we can help change it.

I know this series was a big hit, but I find it slow and a bit difficult to follow.  The basic story is plain enough; but episode after episode, all I see is good guy spying on bad guy and bad guy figuring out that good guy is watching and shifting tactics to keep good guy at bay.  There is a sub-plot: smart-aleck good cop, smarter than his bosses, keeps annoying bosses and keeps getting into trouble.  After six episodes, I was still looking for something to happen.  Not much ever does....  I'll give you this much, however: it's probably more realistic than a lot of the more flamboyantly violent shows out there.  My guess is that real cop-work is more like this than, say, "24."  Another positive (in my book): "The Wire" is a lot less centered on gratuitous nudity, using it only sparingly and in context, unlike many HBO offerings which clearly use skin to compensate for poor content and writing.

There is a reason this show is widely considered one of the best, well written storylines for a dramatic series of all time!!!  It portrays urban crime life realistically and the beaurocratic nature of local (and even federal) governments equally so the dialogue matches suit in that there is a lot of cursing.  For the simple minded, easily offended this show probably isn't for you.  For those that can look past the dialogue and see the complexity of the script and even more complexity of the well developed characters, this show is probably the best overall series ever created and aired.  Don't take my word for it though, spend 10 minutes researching The Wire from reputable websites that critique TV and movies for a living and you will see this is widely considered to be the smartest, deepest, most realistic, and overall best show and series ever created for television!!!

My husband and I watch many TV series (probably too many :-) and if we are ever asked what is the best "cop/detective" series of all time, both of us, without even thinking about it will say, "The Wire." The writing, acting and directing is superb!  The only reason I can think of why someone would not like it is because it is a little gritty. it is not for kids, but if your looking for a good cop program with more than just pretty faces and the same old storylines, try it, I can't imagine you won't enjoy it.

Plot and story and characters and such.  What more could you ask for.  I enjoyed it... even after being told by multiple people how it was one of the greater shows on TV (this usually makes me go into it with a closed mind).  Its free with Prime, why not watch it? Right?

Many others have praised The Wire.  I agree with nearly all that has been written, both among professional critics as well as in the Most Helpful reviews on Amazon.  Please refer to them as to why this series is truly among TV's best.  I want to discuss what many of us have wanted from The Wire for a long long time - The Wire finally in wide screen only on Amazon Instant Video.  Both HBO Go and my DVDs are in the 4:3 ratio.  David Simon, the main creator, declared before that he wanted the show to be more rough visually, that the 4:3 ratio suited the grittiness of the series and was a throwback to that era, the 90's and he believed that the show should not be in HD.  While I applauded that thinking there was always that little voice in my head that said, "Yeah but it would still be great to see the series in a wide screen format."  My wish was granted.  A few days ago I started watching the 1st episode, The Target, on Amazon and initially thought that the screen had been stretched out to fit my 16:9 screen.  I paused the video, put in my Season 1 disc 1 and was astounded that they hadn't done so.  Details in the background that I had had no idea were present were visible.  To me the quality of the stream is also slightly superior to the DVDs visually.  I think I have never been so happy to find that the DVDs I own are now obsolete.

Here's hoping that HBO may one day release the wide screen version of The Wire...

Takes a couple episodes to get invested in this no-frills series, but its character-driven narrative is really compelling after that. There isn't much exposition or predictable plot devices, which is great. The episodes do not have a tidy arc. The show explores the fluid nature of crime, urban dynamics, and people, so if you privilege CSI or Law and Order-type shows that function under a Shakespearean model of order, disorder, re-order, this might confuse or bore you. Also, sorry for how academic that review just sounded.

The best show ever produced.  The plot, character development and social commentary about inner city and governmental red tape open your eyes to the plight of corruption and crime. I have watched this whole series four times and each time, I am amazed at what I missed or misunderstood previously.  This show deserves your undivided attention as there are many characters and plots intertwining at once.  The writers were former journalists and cops in the Baltimore area, so they bring realistic issues to the viewer.  I wish more shows tackled these issues with this much guts and humanity.  You get a full understanding of why things are the way they are--whether it be drugs, gangs, the shipping industry, schools, and the newspaper.  The good guys aren't always good and the bad guys aren't always bad.  Definitely worth the heartache and frustration that you will go through as you unravel these complex characters and storylines.

The Wire is an insightful look at the police, criminals and society.  The story lines examine the fallacy of the drug war and the exploitation of politics.  As the story progresses an examination of the press is placed center front and the blind ambition of some is put on display.  Baltimore is the site of the story, but any city would suffice.  The show does not offer answers to vexing questions of society, instead it gives many a sight they may otherwise miss.  The acting is top notch, the story is compelling, and the Charm City of Baltimore is great.  I highly recommend this show.  All will find something they can appreciate.

HBO has a sterling reputation for the series' it has created over the years.  This series does not disappoint.  I'm coming to this series a good while after it was originally broadcast.  Nevertheless, I've grown addicted to it and am actually on the third episode of season four.

This is the best crime series I've ever seen and I've seen a lot of them.  The cast was largely unknown to me.  Some faces seemed familiar to me, character actors mostly, but no names I would have recognized.  No stars.  No matter.  The cast is amazing and the real stars are the writers.
Viewers are introduced to a crew of world weary cops in Baltimore some of whom have bucked the system and paid the price as they battle the city's drug trade. Each of the characters is a fully realized human being with strengths and weaknesses that play out over the course of the series.  Not only are these cops fighting the drug traffic but they're fighting the corruption of their own bosses and the sleazy politicians who control them.
Like most HBO series, this one has a good deal foul language, nudity, sex and violence.  But, I don't see how the series could have been done without it and still kept a grip on the reality of  degradation, despair and dehumanization that occurs in a big city ghetto.
For those of us who are lucky enough to live in the suburbs, this series is an eye opener. The writers, producers and actors who put this show together should be commended for the insight, unblinking honesty and compassion with which they have treated the source material.  This is a truly great series.

The Wire is clearly one of the most impressive achievements in what we call 'television series'.  Of course, like many others of its kind, we could argue if it really is a television series considering that it is rated R and made for a pay subscription service devoid of advertisers, commercial interruptions and an image of wholesome family values to protect.  But setting aside that, it is so well crafted that I couldn't help but come away from it wondering why most multi-million dollar feature movies aren't this good.  I think that if you like crime dramas The Wire is a must-see.

This is not to say that it is perfect.  I found the overt sexual content, much of it homsexual, to be an unnecessary distraction.  Fortunately, those scenes are brief enough to be forgivable.  At least we can be thankful that blood and gore, while present, isn't as graphic as has become the norm in rated R movies.  It's hard to say how realistic The Wire actually is.  It certainly seems realistic, but without being a veteran police officer in a major city it is hard to say how much of it the producers got right.  My guess is that real police detectives have considerably less freedom than what we see portrayed on The Wire.

We seem to be in a sort of golden age for serial dramas right now.  I think some, like Lost and Fringe are overrated, but The Wire lives up to its hype and is a classic that will continue to be watched decades from now.

Gives a realistic example of how marriages or strained and ruined by the necessities of the job. My daughter and son-in-law have recommended we watch The Wire for some time. We tried the first episode a couple of times and then never went on to the next. It seemed too slow-moving to us and we had problems with understanding some of the ghetto/street language of the main characters. This time we hung in there, and it was well worth it. The show tells the  story of a group of Baltimore cops efforts to take down a drug operation. The story is told from both the perspectives of the police and the members of the drug gang. The culture, politics, and management challenges of both groups play major roles in the drama--and these everyday, real-life issues give the characters depth and make the story whole. The Wire, in its gritty, urban style, is television drama at its best.

The Wire:  A TV-show with many well known actors and a plot that takes too long.  The entire series is about an African American gang leader (located in Baltimore, MD) and his crew of loyal yet underprivileged crack slingers who battle the Baltimore P.D. for reigns over their ghetto.  Each season takes a number of dips into unrelated territory as the group of Baltimore detectives attempt, and of course succeed, at thwarting the master plans of the gang leader (Avon Barksdale).  The name "The Wire" comes from the fact that they the Police wire tap the criminal body they are pursuing. Overall its an interesting story with a drawn out plot that isn't worth it.  IT DOES NOT GET BETTER...

Having attended college in Baltimore around the time this show was being filmed & aired, I can appreciate how real the places and scenes depicted in The Wire are.  Beyond the realism of the backdrop, the characters are real, relateable, flawed, but not idiotic.  Nothing annoys me more than when a a drama moves the plot forward by chronically having characters do idiotic things.  The Wire is the polar opposite of this as the story is moved forward intelligently with very few "now why the <bleep> would he do that?" moments.  Once you get through a few episodes, you'll find yourself binge watching the rest to see how the multiple plots intersect over the course of the entire series.
Watched the series as each season came out. Now it proves how great productions hold up over time. The Wire--all seasons of it--are priceless.

If any metaphor is better than "The Wire" for American capitalism at this stage of,it's development, I don't know what it might be.  Money, the search for it and security has ripped our urban,life apart. The drug trade at the bottom and politics, business at the top,are seen as identical.  They are just different kinds of deals but almost all the interactions between people are transactions.  The city functions either as a faux super-ego repressing uncontrolled desires, or as a super-structure repressing the energy directed toward money and power but which could be re-directed toward class conflict.
  ,the actors are simply wonderful.  The plot lines, maybe a little too mechanical are at least cogent and well,constructed.  Hooray for this light on a dark subject.

I've read about how good of a show The Wire is for years now, so I decided to give it a try. I was skeptical at the beginning because the first episode felt like just another formulaic cop/crime drama. Fortunately, I persevered and was pleasantly surprised by how well written and well acted this show really is. It was an interesting exploration of the far reaching effects and influence of the drug culture, both criminally and politically, in Baltimore. The characters have a depth to them that I have seen in very few other shows and the primary story line was engaging up until the very end. l would highly recommend this show to anyone seeking a quality program and I am excited to start on season two so I can see how all of the characters evolve.

I watched The Wire when it originally aired and have watched episodes from the first season several times.  Now, thanks to Amazon Instant Video, I have been able to binge-watch the entire first season again.  Needless to say, I am a big fan of The Wire and really wanted to give it five stars.  But to be honest, there were a few areas for improvement in the first season that subsequently did get better in future seasons.  The major complaint is the pacing and the payoff.  Yes, The Wire is a slow-moving storm and that is one of its strengths, yet there were times in the first season where the pace really was too slow.  As Detective Freeman said, all the pieces matter, but at the same time, it's tough to know what we're looking at when there is so much to decipher.  As far as the payoff goes, it's slightly annoying that the big payoff for this season really does not occur within the season.  That doesn't mean that this wasn't a first-rate, high quality show - it just means that you have to commit to the entire thing.  I can't judge season one by what happens in season five... so I can only give season one four stars.

This is still my favorite show, and I never get tired of the stories and characters. Each season has its specific focus, although the main characters stay in place. The Wire has a lot to say about a number of social problems, such as poverty, race, drugs, The Drug War, the legal system, public schools, the press. But The Wire handles these with subtlety and depth, rather than the finger waggling and posturing of Oz. There are not really heroes and villains in this version of Bodymore, Murderland. But there are plenty of unforgettable characters, heartbreak, even some laughter, and always the game.

A bit slow, but definitely worth hanging on for a while.  If you aren't interested after episodes 4 or 5, you probably might want to pass (though my favorite episodes were the latter of the series).  The writing is very well done, though there is a lot of profanity and vulgar language which bothers some people (most of the 1-star reviews are from the elderly and/or the bible-thumpers whining about the cursing). It is an interesting way to tell a story, from the traditional "good" and "bad" sides, showing how the line of good and evil is actually blurred, rather than focusing on the cops and allowing them to win every time).  Unlike a lot of other crime shows, this follows one story line throughout the 13 episodes, unlike most TV police dramas which have entirely new plots every episode.  This can make the story very slow at times so ignore the people telling you this is "fast-paced," they have read too many review snippets and think it just means "good." It is definitely good however, worth the 13 hours.  Finally, it helps if you can understand a lot of street and cop lingo, and if you are willing to re-watch parts that were confusing, the story does get complex at times with numerous different characters going all at once and a lot of call-backs to earlier episodes.

One season focuses on the War on Drugs, another on our appalling public education system. The news media, the disappearance of jobs and our politicians are the focus of other seasons.

The show was far ahead of its time.

This was my second time through The Wire (Season 1), and it was even better than my first time through during its original airings on HBO. What makes this a remarkable show is that it feels so authentic and manages to encapsulate the best elements of an excellent police procedural, an in-depth character study, the best gangster films, and all of those "misfits become a great team" films. It's also not afraid to slow burn through all of the elements and allow them to cook up to perfection.

I am no fan of hyperbole in reviews, but this is honestly one of the best (if not the best) shows I've ever seen. Mainly because everyone in the show is written so humanly. In a context where clich could so have so easily won the day, especially in terms of race, crime, sex or violence; this show decides to go deeper.

And don't forget to watch for Omar; a character so original, and almost appallingly visceral in his appeal, you wonder why no one ever wrote and executed someone like this character before this show.

The Wire is unique in that it simultaneously creates empathy from the audience for both the cops and the criminals portrayed. Season one focuses on 2001-ish technology and how criminals outsmart it as well as fall prey to it. It is centered around the street trade of heroin on the rough streets of Baltimore (bal-more as they pronounce it in the show). The show is authentic, realistic, and quite gritty. The characters are all flawed individuals, but utterly human. The show un-apologetically portrays racism, so the thin-skinned should be careful. it is not appropriate for children or adults offended by anything racier than PG-13.
I found the Wire season one to be very compelling.  Enjoyed it very much.

The Wire is an American crime drama television series set and produced in and around Baltimore, Maryland. Created and primarily written by author and former police reporter David Simon, the series was broadcast by the premium cable network HBO in the United States. The Wire premiered on June 2, 2002, and ended on March 9, 2008, comprising 60 episodes over five seasons.

Each season of The Wire introduces a different facet of the city of Baltimore. In chronological order they are: the illegal drug trade, the seaport system, the city government and bureaucracy, the school system, and the print news media. The large cast consists mainly of character actors who are little known for their other roles. Simon has said that despite its presentation as a crime drama, the show is "really about the American city, and about how we live together. It's about how institutions have an effect on individuals. Whether one is a cop, a longshoreman, a drug dealer, a politician, a judge or a lawyer, all are ultimately compromised and must contend with whatever institution to which they are committed."
Tense, coarse, spares no one---gangs, criminal, law enforcement. It reminds me of the French series, "Spiral", both in language and frank portrayal of corrupt public personnel.

If you enjoy cop shows, police procedurals, etc, The Wire is pretty much the best of the best. Made for HBO, it's as gritty and real as it can be. There isn't really a "whodunnit" aspect to the show, since the show spends an equal amount of time on both sides of the law. An excellent balance of character development and story-telling, without turning into a soap opera. I've never been in the Baltimore PD, and I've never lived in the Baltimore projects, but I feel like I know them. Later seasons branch out into whole different areas, too! Spend some time with this series, and you won't be disappointed.

Some things that the makers are clear about:  Not everyone is all-good or all-bad.  For all our good intentions, we don't always do the right thing, and no matter how bad we seem or, indeed, are, we can put others' interests before our own.  Whose code is more honorable, McNultey's or Omar Little's?  Is there even a difference between them?  Are the good guys really good and the bad guys really bad?  If the bad guys are really bad, why are they?

I haven't read all the reviews, but of those I have, one thing not mentioned is how The Wire focuses on the issue of race in America.  If the bad guys are really bad, why?  It's a question we Americans never seem to get around to asking ourselves.  Point fingers, sure we do that.  Excuse ourselves, we do that, too.  Mostly, we get defensive when we might have to acknowledge that our institutions have ignored and left to its own devices a whole segment of society.

Like all great novels, The Wire's conclusion ties everything together.  With scenes like Leandor Sydnor in Judge Phelen's chambers and Duquan Weems in the final montage, we get the feeling that we've been here before, and it makes me cry.

My incentive to begin watching this series (a dozen years after it originally aired) was that a blogger, discussing "Mad Men," said that "The Wire" was also one of the best TV series of all time.  Well, "Mad Men" and "The Wire" are quite different--so different that I can't figure how someone would enjoy/rate them as (superior) equals.  Maybe "The Wire" was unique TV fare for it's time, but as a first time viewer in 2014, I did not find it all that compelling.  After about Episode 5, (Season 1) my interest began to wane.  True, it has gritty realism, and the acting is superior.  But there is not a single character that I am riveted by --with the possible exception of the Lieutenant.  (But he's not in enough scenes in my opinion).  Also, I found it a little hard to follow with just a single viewing of each episode.  But kudos to the series for depicting what is probably a very good ("true to life") look at the world of inner city drugs/police politics/and human drama surrounding the characters who inhabit that milieu.
Addictive...not for the feint of heart. Great job done by technical directors. Can't wait to start on Season 2 today.

I didn't have cable when this was on and heard it was good, so I watched the whole season in a week.  It's a great series to binge-watch because you don't have time to forget all the simultaneous sub-plots going on.

Screen-time is split evenly between the cops and the drug dealers.  Both sides have to deal with similar challenges: managing a big group of people that sometimes back-stab each other, adjusting to new technologies, and deciding how to spread the blame around when things go wrong.  I found it interesting that the cartel's juvenile "hoppers" acting as lookouts, touts, runners, and entry-level "product" handlers were forbidden to get high because it would make them unreliable. . . so in a way, the cartel was keeping at least some kids off drugs!

Cinematography, acting, dialogue and plot are all top-notch.  None of the "dope fiends" are the least bit chic or enviable, and it was clear that the dealers had zero respect for their customers.  Some of the cops' immediate bosses are the type that could make their employees eager to get out on the street and be shot at, just to get out of the office.  At the top police administrative levels, it's "Dilbert" with guns; any work that gets done is in spite of them rather than because of them.  The cartel's management structure is just as rigidly hierarchical but seems a lot more cohesive, possibly because the alternative is generally a cap in one's a--.

On-screen sex scenes are short but graphic - people bothered by that kind of thing should maybe give it a miss.
